39620142.review:
Lakeview Cabin Collection is pure throwback in video game form, both in its content and its graphical style.  The game is technically proficient; the characters are all large and easy to read and the interactive objects don't bleed in to the background.

For the price of one game you're basically getting five.  Each scenario harkens back to a specific genre of film and requires different strategy to complete.  Even if you manage to survive a scenario (no small feat) there is still the prospect of getting the "good" ending for each, as well as digging deeper in to the enigmatic Lakeview mythos.

Great game, 10/10 would recommend to anyone who loves adventure games or classic horror.

Great game for horror enthusiasts.

39399417.review:
Game bought in a bundle

Once I read that whoever created Lakeview Cabin Collection must be a genius of the macabre ... and hell, he was right.
A clear homage to horror films of the 80s, this puzzle game gives you for each episode (there are several, with very different themes and mechanics among them) a very clear objective to fulfill but with a great freedom on HOW to fulfill it. The result? As you explore each chapter you will experience terror, WTF, laughter, death, frustration, surprise, disbelief, more WTF, more frustration and in the end (after many many deaths) a great feeling of victory. His style of pixel art is incredible and very consistent with the theme of the game, granting freedom to the developer (and therefore the players) of trespassing limits with a boldness that I had not seen before.

Will everyone like it? HELL NO, I love the game in its entirety but many characteristics that are part of its charm can provoke a deep rejection. The difficulty is very high, requiring not only a great planning of what to do but also an almost perfect timing and sometimes only blind luck. Careful planning can be transformed into a gore fest in a matter of seconds. You can start a chapter (or the whole game) without knowing what to do, who or what killed all your characters in the last seconds or what is happening in general and after several attempts ... continue completely lost.

If you manage to pass all that bitter taste and get to the moment when the sweet understanding comes, good for you, I congratulate you. This liquor is not for everyone, but for the people who will like it, it is an unforgettable experience.

In short, this is a game that you will love or hate, if you have interest in horror games, do not mind pixel art, grotesque humor and play blind a game where you need to die many times to uncover how to advance (and sometimes to move forward) I recommend it completely. For my part, this game has been one of the best things I have discovered in a bundle, I send my congratulations to the developer and I assure you that I will buy his next game at full price.

36916495.review:
Excellent tribute to horror films that's open enough to give the player a few different experiences:

1) Goof off. It's easy to have a blast messing around haplessly and interacting with the movie worlds and characters within them... often with unexpected and gory results. 
2) Roleplay your own story. You control four protagonists. Set them up and have them interact with a living scenario of death and horror however you want.
3) Do the legit playthrough. Work to figure out how each scenario can resolved and completed.

However you play Lakeview Cabin Collection, it's a satisfying experience.

Sin embargo algo que tengo que recalcar mucho es que la parte 5 del juego, en mi opinion y de varias personas mas es muy injusto, no te dire lo que sucede, pero, uno de los codios que tienes que usar esta escondido en una secuencia de sonido musical de una parte del capitulo, entre otros varios codigos que son dificeles de encontrar; en esta parte te recomiendo que usas una guia. Pero por otro lado las partes 2 4 y 6 las puedes jugar sin ninguna guia, y te recomiendo que no las uses en estas partes porque al darte cuenta de que has pasado un capitulo sin la ayuda de nadie te sentiras satisfecho contigo.

Lo recomiendo bastante para las personas que les gusta el terror, tal vez el juego no tenga graficos que te puedan atraer, al estar jugando no te importara, porque te desenvuelve en escenarios unicos e historias interesantes aparte de ser muy perurbadoras para algunos.

NOTA: me gustaria que este juego siga entregando mas capitulos, porque realmente el juego es maravilloso, es retorcido y te hace sentir que estas jugando en una pelicula.

RE-CO-MEN-DA-DO

35036886.review:
This strategy-horror hybrid is a retro-themed series of lengthy levels (four of them), each one of which parodies horror films from the 70s and 80s. Between a level on Friday the 13th, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Halloween. and Alien, the game offers unique objectives/design that test a player's intuition and reaction time. It most certainly doesn't hold your hand, and completing a level by surviving is greatly rewarding. In one, you have to kill three serial killers; in another you have to avoid a cultist family while collecting gas, and so on. There's a lot of variation and the game most certainly never grows stale.

In some ways, I really enjoyed this game and I want to give it a thumbs up. However, the boss fights are absolutely unforgiving. So much so, that a very tiny mistake can force you to restart the entire game. This is atrocious game design, particularly for a game in which mistakes are easy to make (due to time or otherwise). Because of this, I can't fully recommend this game. The point of gaming is fun, and fun doesn't describe my entire experience with this title.

34875224.review:
Okay. Lakeview is nothin' but bare-bones pixel graphics. However, if you have even an iota of imagination to fill in the grisly details that the game often mercifully omits, guess what?

This is easily one of the single most hinder-clenchingly, sick, twisted, and terrifying games ever made.

It's a work of macabre genius! This game goes places that no triple A title will ever dare. It's stuff that'd make Clive Barker blush. And the minimalistic visuals only help the horror, inviting your mind fill in all the gorey details. The well-placed musical stings perfectly accent the aural ambience that gives every part of this collection of micro-terror titles a constant sense of dread and suspense.

My only gripe is that the original flash game, which inspired this anthology, is not available in this set.
It's freely available on any number of sites, but its absence is still something of a bummer.

Fun-sized morbid morsels for your next spooky gaming binge of Haloween horrors.
Dig in.

34741409.review:
This game is really fantastic. It's hard to fit what it does into a genre--it's a pixel, horror, survival, puzzle, adventure. There, I think that broadly describes it.

The mechanics are simple--run around switching between characters, pick up or use objects in the environment, avoid the baddies, learn how to defeat them. But it's the attention to detail and lee-way in how things can play out, that really shines. 

It's tough, and you'll die a lot probably before even starting to figure anything out. Dying, both by player error, and getting killed in an entertaining or frightening way, is all part of the process. But with repeated attempts and careful observation, it is possible.

Recrea tus clasicas peliculas de terror ochenteras con este juego estilo retro. 
Reviviras casi los mismos momentos de aquellas peliculas como "Viernes 13", "Poltergeist", "El amanecer de los muertos" y un largo etc. En la cual manejaremos siempre a un grupo de 4 protagonistas envueltos en un escenario determinado para escapar o derrotar al villano en cuestion que amenaza con sus vidas.

 Y como juego de terror que se respeta, los puzzles jugarán un papel muy importante dentro de las mecanicas. El punto malo tambien es este enfoque, donde algunos de estos pueden ser demasiado ambiguos para resolver con su jugabilidad simple, (la cual se basa en levantar casi cualquier objeto y lanzarlo o usarlo como arma.) por lo que te quedarias bastante tiempo dando vueltas durante todo el escenario hasta en la que de casualidad hagas algo que active un script para que la trama "avance" por asi decirlo. Las unicas pistas que tienes son pequeño documentos con pistas muy pequeñas sobre que se podria hacer y tu intuicion al ver visto alguna de estas peliculas a las cuales hace referencia.

El juego llega a traer sus buenos sustos y ver como si eres un poco descuidado tus personajes van muriendo sorpresivamente generandote tension; a su vez tambien hay distintos toques de humor que te sacara unas risas. 

Recomendado, si.

34504307.review:
Game is clearly inspired by the old friday the 13th movies. If you enjoy those films or simply find them hilarious. This is most likely game for you.
You are not told what to do but that is simply the charm of the game. You control four characters and attempt to stop, avoid and/or escape what ever disaster is eventually hapenning in the "chapter".
Game has four "chapters" with each lot of interactions that eventually you learn and exploit to reach your desired ending.
Completing a chapter with "Good Ending" unlocks special mode for that chapter.
Chapter One: Four summer campers and dog get attacked by very resiliant killer on a small island. Bonus Mode - Zombies!
Chapter Two: Four people are stuck on a property with very sadistic family that have created obstacle course of death. Bonus mode - Treasure Hunt
Chapter Three: Four youngsters are attacked by ghost like serial killer. (This one is really cryptic but forgiving as you can die and continue your progress. Returning from death is big part of the puzzle)
Chapter Four: Inspired by dead space. This one is key hunt in very limited time. I don't want to spoil this chapter because it was quite satisfying to figure out how to beat it.
Epilogue: After you beat all four chapters you can find sort of prequel. There is no much player choise in it, just visual storytelling.
Secret Level: It's not much of a secret level. It's the "Chapter selection" level. It doesn't seem to tie into the story. just fun easter egg that is hinted at in first minute of the game when you are thaught the controls.

I'm not usually a fan of 8-bit games., but this game was really impressive. There's no dialogue because none is needed. Everything story related can be found in the discussion forums by the devs, or you can put the pieces together yourself from the games environment. 

This game holds Lakeview Cabin II, III, IV, V, & VI. The movie theater's hub houses doors that let you choose which chapter you want to play, though the doors are only labled 3/4/5/6 (no number 2). The second door chapter is secret (I don't know why). As I'm writing this I've completed Lakeview Cabin II & III. 

There's a suprising amount of freedom in this game a player can take to try to stop the killers. The music is fantastic & the sound effects are great. Unfortunately the first Lakeview Cabin game was a flash game, so it wasn't included in this collection. If you're thinking about getting this game, I suggest playing the original Lakeview Cabin game first to see if you'd find it enjoyable. I've linked it below. 

http://www.newgrounds.com/portal/view/627444

The movie theater 'hub' in this game that allows you to choose the chapter you want to play even has it's own secrets & killer to face.

31380265.review:
Hey guys!

Do you want a game that makes you feel:
Nostalgic
Scared
Inadequate

Then Lakeview cabin collection is for you!

Lake view Cabin collection is a fun re-release of an older browser game. It is entirely 2D and with little pixel-arty graphics. 

It's very simple, straightforward controls and wandering about just allows you to discover fun little Easter eggs in the game, picking up and throwing backpacks makes items fall out, falling off high platforms causes your character to lose a leg, which you can then use as a weapon, there is even pixel orgies to set up!

But it doesn't end there in your little world of pounding pixelized six packs and hitting pixelized bongs (which make the screen/controls all jankey) there are terrifying copyright infringing bad guys determined to come hunt you down and turn your characters in to gory piles of pixelized flesh, bone and sinew. In order to defeat/run away from these guys you are given the task of setting up traps and collecting weapons in a not-so-linear little world.

And it's hard... Like really hard, you will die, and you will die a lot, which really you know... When you are playing a glorified flash game which is all almost cutesy pixel arty... its a little patronising. And I don't mean to sound patronising, Lakeview cabin collection nails a retro pixel art world, it even start with a pixelly VHS going into a machine! Its spot on, really cool stuff. But those pixel bad guys are scarier than Devil May Cry: Dante must Die bosses!

Anyways, game is great, go spend some of your hard-earned on it, then let it fester in your steam library for a couple of years, then play it.

Love and you want me to put my pixels where?

Richie X

30497353.review:
Did you ever want to drink beer, play with fire, shoot your friends into the face, run away from the horror in the sewers, fight off an alien infection and throw the dead bodies of your former friends towards Rednecks to defend yourself? Then this may be a game you should take a closer look.

[b]Lakeview Cabin Collection[/b] is a collection of four plus one short games (plus another very short drug induced fever dream game) centering around well known horror movies. You start the game in front of the cinema which is at the same time the main hub to choose which episode from Lakeview Cabin III to VI you want to watch/play and also a mini-level itself. All movies have in common that there is absolutely no hand-holding. It is a sandbox experience where you have to figure out everything yourself compirsing with what an object does, where you can/have to use it and actually starting with what object you are holding since it is not always clear (due to the simplified graphic). This is often fun and interesting, mostly refreshing and sometimes really, really frustrating. Also in common is the fact that in every episode you can switch between four playable characters. But let's look at each episode separately.

Lakeview Cabin III is the "first" movie you can choose and also the simplest one. You and your friends are counselors in a camp and everything is fun until something murderous will start hunting you. The goal here is simply surviving and killing what is hunting you. Every item is always in the same place so you can slowly refine your strategy. Find the shotgun, try to chop it down with the axe or just burn it with fire. Or feel the despair losing one character after another.

Lakeview Cabin IV is the second movie. You and your friends ran out of fuel in front of a mansion somewhere in nowhere. You have to explore the surroundings and find four canisters and bring them back to the car. In contrast to the previous episode there is some randomization including the order of rooms and where what items/enemies are placed. Sounds easy, right? Did I mention the bloodthirsty Rednecks? Well, still easy. Did I mention the rat mutants?

Lakeview Cabin V is both fascinating and frustrating. Like episode III everything is always in the same place. Goal is to put an undieable killer to its final rest with the help of some demons. In contrast to all other episodes you can't really die here. It is more of a puzzle episode. But here the sandboxing gets really frustrating because the puzzles are really hard to figure out. Episode V appeared some time after the initial release. As such there was a community waiting for it and figuring everything out themselves. Brilliant idea on the paper but frustrating in reality since you have nearly no chance to get everything alone.

Lakeview Cabin VI is more action orientated again. It is more difficult in the puzzle aspect then episode III and IV but a lot easier than V. Problem is that you may be burnt out after episode V and not paying much attention to the obvious hints. In this episode you play a group of janitors, cleaning the space station after a party. Places are always same but item placement is randomized. This would be an easy job but someone might not have read the memo about not getting infected by alien parasites. And if you don't find it fast enough hell might break loose on the station in no time. And even if you find it ...... there is still good chance to die.

All in all there is much diversity in the episodes but you need to have a small experimentor gene in you (because using guides from the beginning would be boring as .....). In every episode there is also a small mini-game which can occupy you for some minutes. You can unlock those by completing the episode the first time.
The complete package is in total very enjoyable but you may find yourself burnt out slightly by episode V. Also do not be fooled by the cute graphics. The game can be - at times - surprisingly suspenseful and violent.

PS: If you have any question just write in the comments and I will try to get back to them as fast as possible.

29573457.review:
I have actually played this about an hour total besides the Steam-time.  

This is a sprite-based sandbox homage to 80s horror and creature films - films I love a lot.  You play as multiple young people trying to survive against various baddies or monsters.  There is no apparent goal other than to survive, hence the sandbox.  You can pickup and use various things around the area.  Little is explained, not even the controls - they're meant to be contextual, as there is a button prompt when you are near interactable items.  

However, I found the simplistic nature of all this combined with the cryptic nature to be a major turnoff.  I was basically walking around bored waiting for the bad guys to show up (takes a long time on the first area), then when they do I did not find myself engaged enough to even really desire to fight them - not helped by very short reach attacks.  

I pretty quickly realized there are ways to spring traps on the bad guys, and that's probably the real way to survive, but the very difficulty in even understanding what does what, coupled with how quickly you can kill yourself (throw a lantern by accident in a room, you're dead).  I just lost interest really fast, as I realized it'd take a ton of retries and trial and error.  This reminded me a bit of a rogue-lite, in a sense, only without the scaling skill set you usually have to acquire in those games.  Of course, I have mixed experiences with rogue-lites personally - if you like them a lot, your mileage may vary.

I get there's clearly meant to be some humor involved as well, and that just didn't quite work for me either.  Watching somebody else play would probably have been funnier actually, and I may give that a try one day.

If you really enjoy tinkering around in sandboxes, you may get more out of it though.   For me, it just doesn't work.

29513213.review:
TO CLARIFY BEFORE I BEGIN WRITING THIS REVIEW I HAVE NOT FINISHED ALL OF THE CHAPTERS HOWEVER I HAVE PLAYED ENOUGH TO WRITE THIS REVIEW.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

To sum this game up as a slasher parody would probably be sufficent enough however I feel that it is a little bit more difficult to accuratly describe this game. For starters this game is based off horror movie cliches and popular slasher flicks while at the same time presenting a unique approach at the horror genre. For a 2D pixelated game this one actually proved to be nerve racking at times. I can not describe how absolutly terrifyed I was the first time the killer showed up in LVC3. Moving onward the games soundtrack compliments the 80's/90's vibe the game gives off. The use of keyboard synths and dark ambient instrumentals proves to make the experiance all the more chilling. The game also has elements of dark and often crude humor such as going to the bathroom in order to drop a item from the ceiling or commiting incest in order to summon a monster.

To break down each episode and how it makes itself stand out from the others: 
LVC3 puts in the place of a group of camp conselours as they are stalked by a murderous duo on the island.
LVC4 has you play as a band whose tour bus has broken down at a mansion inhabitated by cultists and a slaughterhouse where the Leatherface-esque "Pigman" lurks awaiting its next victim. This installment introduces a sanity effect in which as you kill people the screen reddens and various hallucinations occur.
LVC5 has you playing as the standard 80's teenagers as they try to fend off a mysterious killer. This chapter has a unique "underworld" effect in which dead charecters can be "resurrected" which plays a key role in the episode. This chapter also had multiple endings one of which requires beating LVC3 without any charecters dying at any point.
LV6 takes place persumably in the future on a space station where a virius has broken out infecting members of the crew and presenting you with the mission of gathering survivors off the ship and into escape pods while fighting against the alien virius. This finale to the series has a item transportation system eliminating the need to travel everywhere to get one particular item.

There are however a few things that I would like to see changed or atleast fixed. For starters the gamepad reccomended sequence at the start of the game seems unnessacary as I made large progress in the game using a standard QWERTY keyboard. Therefore I feel that this sequence is not important and should be removed. My second problem is that in LVC5 the killer seems to have a very odd spawn rate as at the start of the chapter the killer will spawn constantly often interfering with trying to preform the deathmarks ritual while later on near the end of the chapter he will almost cease to spawn causing long waiting periods in order to finish the chapter. 

Before rating this game I should also point out that this game is equal parts skill and luck as you must have good reflexes and thorough understanding of the controls while at the same time it is possible to breeze through some areas purely off of random events or lucky item spawns. This all being said I would highly reccomend this game to any slasher horror fan or someone just looking for something fun and original. Personally I would rate this game at a 9/10. I hope my review sways your opinion of this amazing game and convinces you to buy it.

29351128.review:
[h1] B級ホラームービーの登場人物になり、生き残りをかけてサイコパス達と戦う [/h1]

シリーズ4部作＋オマケ要素がまとまったコレクション版。
「湖の畔にあるキャンプ場のコテージに、男女のグループで泊まる」など、アメリカンホラーの王道シチュエーションにおいて、襲い来る殺人鬼を倒し、生き残って脱出するのが目的となる。

弾がないショットガン、ガソリン缶、カナヅチ、ビール、懐中電灯、トイレ掃除用の吸盤など、さまざまなオブジェクトを利用してマップ（比較的狭い）を探索し、敵を排除していくのが基本。ポイント＆クリック系アドベンチャーに戦闘を組み合わせたような作品だが、さまざまな解法が用意されているというサンドボックス要素も。

クリアするだけならば1エピソード20分程度でなんとかなりそうな難易度だが、いわゆる隠しエンディング（goodエンディング）に到達しようとすると、『たけしの挑戦状』並みに理不尽な難易度に跳ね上がるようだ。
見かけのようにカジュアルなゲームだと思っていると、殺人鬼に何十回となく刺されるハメになることだろう。

8ビット風ながらツボを突いた恐怖演出にはドキドキさせられるが、『キャビン』（2012年）のようなお約束系ホラー映画が好きならば非常にオススメ。

28925475.review:
Lakeview Cabin collection is a continuation to the freeware game, Lakeview Cabin and it's just like it's predecessor.
Lakeview Cabin Collection theme is set around classic cult horror movies in the sandbox genre, that asks the question: What would YOU do if you were set in one of this movies?
You have 4 stages to choose, each of them is based on a different cult horror movie.

Let's define what is a sandbox:

Sandbox comes from a literal sandbox where the children play and [b]do whatever they want[/b]...

[b]THEY DO WHATEVER THEY WANT[/b]

In a sandbox game you have minimal restrictions and you can do [b]whatever you want[/b], of course there are tasks you can do, but they [b]are optional[/b] and you can [b]choose to do them whenever you want[/b]

The problem here is that those tasks aren´t optional at all and they come in whenever THEY want.
Let's say you are playing the first stage LVC III (Based in Friday the 13th) and you are playing around the stage and experimenting with stuff randomly and suddenly... The killers appear and since they are impossible to kill unless you have a predefined strategy you die.

Thanks to it's sandbox nature the game is esentially a trial-and-error game, the cheapest of all games, you can't see the incoming danger [b]unless you already experiencied it or you readed a guide[/b]. This happens through all the game, since LVC III to LVC V.
Examples:
LVC III: You don't know when will the danger strike and when it does you are not prepared for it, since the first killer will take the first weapon he finds and will proceed to kill you, the only weapon he finds and cant do anything is the teddy bear which is found by taking a dump (I don't know how would anybody figure out that)
The second killer has a default weapon and is the fastest character, you need a strategy to kill him.
The third killer appears at a fixed location and [b]you can't attack her by the front, you need to attack her from behind and with a specific weapon, the only way of killing her is to be with the right weapon at the right location at the right time, thing that you won't know until you played the same level constantly [/b]

On top of the trial-and-error nature the game is also incredibly cryptic and it "complements" the trial and error.
Example: In order to get a key you need to bang a woman in LVC III

The game on counted situations wants you to do puzzles in a very specific order, which is completly stupid since the game is non-linear and the puzzles are incredibly cryptic too, rarely they will give you a clue and when they do you won't understand it because the thing that it wants you to do doesn't make sense.

The worse chapter by far is LVC V, why? Because it's full of puzzles! Lots of cryptic puzzles in a very specific order!
In fact, let me pass you an image that "explains" you how to get the best ending.

http://staycalmcursory.deviantart.com/art/Lakeview-Cabin-V-Best-Ending-A-Guide-638647616

Did you understood anything? 
Exactly.
Basically the game wants you to die in 4 different way with each character
summon 3 monsters, 1 by building up a doll whose parts are hidden in the Limbo, summoning another by playing a videogame in a specific way and other by placing the characters that were killed in 4 specific ways in a summoning ritual.
The game needs that you go to 6 different doors in Limbo and that you 6 different things in a specific order, you also need to call 3 different number on a specific order, you need to know a combination show in a secret room of the previous stage, you need to get a strange box, you need to replay LVC III and throw the box to the third killer and I think you got the point.

LVC V is all that is wrong in the game at it''s finest.

The game is not hard is [b]cheap[/b] with a lot of cheap traps and cryptic puzzles

It's a cheap game based around the horrible trial-and-error principle, with a bunch of cryptic puzzles that are almost impossible to resolve without resorting to a guide all thanks to it's sandbox nature, lack of logical clues and cryptic nature. 

The devs had a very [b]very[/b] specific idea of how you had to do stuff

The game also has a combat system and it´s atrocious, the controls are incredible wonky and the main reason you can't properly defend yourself against the killers is due to this jaggy combat system that thinks that you must overlap the killer's sprite in order to damage it, the controls while are simple the problem is that they can be used for multiple things and they feel really wonky.

On it´s favor I can say that since the game is fractured in 4 stages it allows different gameplay and objectives, LVC III doesn't look anything like LVC IV and all the stages have different missions and gameplay strategies, for example, LVC IV has a sanity meter (it´s not like the meter matters there but meh)
The game also has cheap jumpscares but they can be counted with fingers of one hand

And as a sandbox it also fails, the main point in the sandbox is to give you "total" freedom, here in sandboxes, the plot is optional, is a side story that you can choose to take while you do everything you want. Here, you "can" do everything you want but the plot still gets forced into your mouth, if you don't do what the game wants you to do you will lose, if you don't do anything in LVC VI, you will be a victim of the outbreak, if you don't do anything on LVC III the killers will get you as they will always appear, if you want to do stuff in LVC IV you can't because the people inside the house will kill you if you dont proceed how the game wants you, if you wanna do anything in LVC V, Good luck! You will never get anywhere. The threat gets forced in your mouth either way. Wouldn't it be awesome if we truly got total freedom? Like controlling the killers so we can recreate the way we want our cheap horror B movie? Like the game advertises as?

While this game has an unusual pixelart aesthetic (Even then, it's not really THAT good) and good creepy tunes that can make the game genuinely creepy on counted situations but even the music lacks in a lot of moments and overall it's technic aspect can't compensate it's horrible game design and poor programming.

28920400.review:
Lakeview Cabin Collection features a romp of 80s style horror parody platformer-puzzle hybrids in which the goal is for your group of friends to survive the onslaught of a mysterious and cliché killer. The 4 chapters start at 3 for some reason and each has their own team and theme. In Lakeview Chapter 3, it’s a bunch of spring break types vacationing at a cabin haunted by a murderous duo.  Chapter 4 seems like a page pulled right out of The Hills Have Eyes with a little Texas Chainsaw massacre mixed in. Chapter 5 is a Jason-Freddy combination and Chapter 6 practically screams Alien. The content is all episodic and can be entered in any order you choose from the movie theater hub level.

Stages in LCC can be a bit cryptic as you start each one in somewhat peaceful conditions and it may seem as if there is nothing to do except wander around. This is an easy mistake to make as just about every stage has some sort of timer before various events are thrown into motion, potentially sealing your doom if you are not prepared enough. Each stage has a variety of weapons for you to fight back against the killers with, and careful use of combined forces is absolutely necessary if you want to be able to take them down. 

If you plan on playing this game without a guide, expect to spend a lot of time doing trial and error before you finally figure things out. Some chapters are pretty obscure so don’t feel bad if you have to pull up a guide for help as there are plenty in the steam community. Either way, I managed to put in around 13 hours in Lakeview Cabin Collection which is a great deal for the price. Worth picking up if you’re into cheesy 80s horror movies and enjoy a good puzzle-mystery.

28770484.review:
** One-sentence review:  Unique, Difficult but Fun Old School Game **

The Lakeview Cabin Colleciton began with a flash game on Newgrounds and since has evolved into a game with mechanics of the early days of the PC gaming industry but with some modern twists.  This will either make or break the game for you because you're given nearly nothing in terms of instructions and the puzzles and planning quickly ramp up to extreme difficulty.

Yet this is part of the game's charm; nothing is really explained and the best learning is through experimentation.  There's little you can rely on from other games to help you -- there will be no prompts, the clues will be subtle and the combination of pixelated graphics and a complete lack of any examination functionality means you have to learn by playing and trying different, sometimes ridiculous things.

While this might seem like a negative -- and for some players it really will be -- there's the other factor that experimentation is a lot of fun, especially in the first episode.  Your failures and successes have the potential to be spectacular.  You're free to make the characters do anything you want, and a great deal of the hazards that apply to you also apply to most everyone else.  There's a great amount of darkly humourous value to be had in managing to kill someone with popcorn or exploding something with more force than what was expected.  You're free to smash your own allies with anything you can lay your hands on (including whole/parts of bodies) or engage in various kinds of lewd behaviour.

Each episode has its own drastically different style and game play all while using the same engine.  Episode 1 (LCIII) allows for a lot of juvenile humour and is the most open ended.  Episode II (LCIV) is suddenly a lot more serious, which is surprisingly effective as it still retains some of the goofier elements like very make-shift weapons (candles, flares, bodies).  Episode III (LCV) is suddenly a full-on hardcore puzzle game (including retaining the modern design of being unable to actually lose).  Episode IV (LCVI) suddenly throws things in an entirely new-yet-old direction, and this doesn't even cover the Hub world with its hidden surprises.

Including solving a puzzle using vomit in the Underworld.  It wasn't meant to be solved that way, but it worked.

The Lakeview Cabin Collection is a rare comedy-horror combination in the gaming world -- it's very darkly funny, and yet also manages to rank up the tension, suspense and horror (it's not scary, but it is unsettling and purposely becomes moreso if you analyze it).  

Plus every time someone gets a rake in the face it makes me laugh.  Moreso when it's a menacing killer.  Who's on fire.  While psycho strings are playing.

PROS:
- Extremely imaginative and creative engine.  Almost everything has multiple uses.  Many things have hidden uses or amusing mis-uses.
- Well done pixel graphics; starts out simple and then gets surprising.  The pixel graphics also match the budget-restricted feel of old horror movies.
- The game FEELS like a series of horror cult classics with appropriate musical stings and over-the-top, pixelated gore.
- Ridiculous combat.
- Extremely clever puzzles.

CONS:
- Hit detection and consistency is off; it was designed so certain enemies really do need to be hit from the back but in a game where characters react to just about anything the no-sell comes off more like poor hit detection rather than being ineffective.  Thrown item hit detection is also a bit wonk, and some items can only be used once for no reason and with a lack of universal consistency it feels more 'off' than it should.
- The complete lack of real guidance may turn off some players.
- Some mechanics take a leap in logic; to fuel a minibus for example one must hurl the can towards the 'right spot' on the bus as opposed to putting in an object use button or automatically using it (like shells are automatically placed in the shotgun).  This stands out more when most objects are fairly intuitive.


Overall, if you are a fan of horror, a fan of ludicrous game mechanics that lets you do things just because you wanted to, and enjoy some truly old-school game play from a time before established practices, this is probably the game for you.

If you prefer games that plainly explain things -- including mechanics and story -- you might find the Lakeview Cabin Collection more frustrating than fun.

I received this game as a gift.  I would buy for full price.

28021985.review: This is a really strange game and I can't say I've ever played something quite like it (except for Lego Star Wars in a roundabout way). It provides you with no direction whatsoever as you're plopped into a horror movie scenario (Friday the 13th, Halloween, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, and Aliens) and forced to find your own way of survival. Despite the retro graphics (which are overdone in indie games at this point, but oh well) the survival challenge is extremely realistic. Things that you wouldn't expect to be able to kill you in a video game will kill you and things that look like useful items only end up being useful if used in a realistic way. It's definitely worth experiencing, but I recommend buying it on sale due to a few major omissions from the developer that damage the overall experience. Lakeview Cabin would be a perfect fit for local multiplayer, it would be seamless, but instead you're forced to play single player and awkwardly cycle through four playable characters at a time. The other omission is allowing the player to distinguish between throwing, dropping, and "using" items. This game is 99% interacting with items and it gets frustrating when you can't do something as simple as throwing them on command.

26836778.review:
This game is steal on sale. It's simple presentation hides a lot of gameplay, depth, and story. In each of the game's 4 worlds (plus 2 secret worlds) you'll be placed in a setting reminiscent of a classic horror movie such as Friday the 13th or Halloween. Your goal is to survive and beat the killer. 
But the game keeps switching up the gameplay on you with each new level. Level 1 is mostly a sandbox where you're free to approach the situation how you want, whereas level 3 is closer to a point and click puzzle game with how you have to decode what the next step is (this one might require a guide). 
Then there's the secret lore hidding in every level that reveals the connecting story between levels if you're willing to go crazy and find every secret the game holds (prepare to replay certain levels A LOT), kinda reminds me of FNAF that way.
And while the game may be goofy and humorous in its presentation the scary moments are genuinly scary. Fighting the Baby Mask Killer is still as stressful and terrifying as the first time I did it.
Even with 16 hours clocked into this seemingly simple game I still have a lot left to find, especially since some levels gain an additional hard mode once you finish them.
Like I said, an absolute steal on sale.

26105777.review:
Lakeview Cabin Collection

Alright guys, I’m going to lay it all out there. As the spook-time approaches us, it’s times like these where it is a golden opportunity to get comfy, and enjoy the season for all it’s worth. This game is prime for that. Done in the style of the retro days this game pays homage to the horror greats, in only what can be described as a horror-comedy-puzzle game. On the surface it’s 4 levels. But it is so much deeper than that, with 2 secret levels, an epilogue and a plethora of references, possibilities and combinations, this game is not dull for a moment. Surprisingly enough it keeps you on your toes despite the pixel-ness. It’s great fun to have everything fall to pieces in the blink of an eye. No matter how prepared you are, one wrong move, mistake, innocent oversight causes everything to come tumbling down and you, your dog and your friends are dead. It’s a golden game with great atmosphere, fun times and enjoyability to be had. Regardless of the scenarios you find yourselves in, this game is suitable for both fans and newcomers to the genre alike. If you’re interested in everything going haywire, confusion, spooks, and a fair amount of laughs, this game is for you.  Enjoy.

10/10, would die with my pixels hanging out again

----------------------

Okay, let's get serious. This game is amazing for it's price. It's a complex puzzle box from the depths of hell! It's filled with all kinds of secrets, changing gameplay, gratuitous violence, sex, human sacrafice and amazing atmosphere for something that just uses the pixel graphics!

The game consists of four levels based on horror movies: Lakeview Cabin III, Lakeview Cabin IV, Lakeview Cabin V, and "Cabin 6." I'm torn between whether I like V or IV more.

III is quite simple: Kill the killers before they murder each and every one of you in your drunk, naked sleep. There's a lot of ways, the zipline, burning them to a crisp, getting really ballsy and going toe to toe with them with a weapon (hasn't worked for me yet) or ramming a highly explosive motor scooter into them, and more! [spoiler]Hide the body, don't let him see it![/spoiler]

IV is a loving sort of parody of Texas Chainsaw Massacre. You control a band who's van has chosen to break down in the worst possible place - an old mansion full of cannibals... and giant rats. The rooms change, the weapons change, even the secret rooms change with each playthrough! It's especially satisfying to beat the crap out of the cannibals and listen to that rocking tune when your sanity gets low.

V is a more puzzle oriented. I've never seen the movie it's based on, but I think it's supposed to be based on Halloween. In this one, you will have fun killing your own characters to go in and out of the netherworld. This level is very complex. To get the best ending, you have to do things in the previous games. But the A ending is worth it if you want to see an ending where everyone is happy (as opposed to III and the unfortunate cannibals whom you will have no doubt wiped out to the last man)

Cabin 6 takes the story into space. One of the crew is infected with an alien thingy. You have to find them and quarentine them before they mutate. It's argueably easiest when you know the proceedure. Additionally, you have to evacuate the rest of the crew (if there's any left.) The aliens look pretty neat too.

[spoiler]Cabin II is... an epilogue. Yes, you heard me. You go through all the other levels, and then you go to the dark door in the theatre and go inside. You get to see all the story elements strung together nicely. [/spoiler]

The only thing I lament about it is that the series is finished and that we will not get anymore lakeview cabin. But all good things must come to an end.

...and that there's no soundtrack. I could listen to [spoiler]her song[/spoiler] all day long.

Buy the damn game. Then go out and see some horror movies.




[spoiler] Beware the sewers! [/spoiler]

24550809.review:
I HIGHLY recommend this lovingly-constructed tribute to the '80s' most iconic horror films.  It has the puzzle-solving feel of old Sierra On-Line adventure games (e.g. King's Quest and Quest for Glory), in that there are several well-defined obstacles, which can be overcome in a variety of ways, limited mostly--but not entirely--by the player's creativity.  

The "collection" features four full games, each one a tribute to a set of horror films from the '80s.  Respectively, the games pay tribute to the Friday the 13th series; The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Hills Have Eyes; Halloween and A Nightmare on Elm Street; and finally Alien and The Thing.  The game's own lore recapitulates some major themes from these films as well, besides that of masked, blade-wielding serial killers: there are twisted family relations, backwoods satanic cults, revenge from beyond the grave, haunted video games, plus references to an in-game "true story" on which the Lakeview Cabin "movies" are based.  It's tempting to say more, but I don't want to spoil anything!

In each game, you control four protagonists--usually teenagers, the likes of which get butchered by slasher-movie antagonists.  In each game, you have a limited amount of time, and a specific set of resources--some hidden, some out in the open--to prepare for a confrontation with at least one serial killer.  It's your job to switch back and forth between your protagonists in real time, find whatever you can use as a weapon, set traps, and manipulate your tiny environment to your advantage, so that your whole team can survive a horror movie.  The creator obviously loves '80s slasher films, and the multitudinous references, alongside a compelling lore, will captivate anyone who's hosted a marathon of scary movies during Halloween.

It's best played with a controller.  I have a Mac, so I just grabbed a generic PS-type controller with a USB port from Best Buy, and it works like a charm.  The controls are incredibly responsive, and the interface is reminiscent of old NES games like Super Mario Bros 2, or Chip and Dale Rescue Rangers, where you can pick things up from your environment and throw them.  (The game's creater--just one dude--mentioned the latter NES game as inspiration, and it shows.)  Additionally, the game bears an inescapable similarity to Maniac Mansion--i.e. shifting control between characters to deal with antagonists, who move in a real-time environment.

The score, appropriately, is reminiscent of John Carpenter.  Most of it is triggered by events: stacatto strings punctuate every stab wound; plodding, low-register, single-note piano hits accompany the killers' approach; it's scored like the horror films to which it pays tribute.  As such, it's nothing you'll want to play in your car on the way to work--no more than any other horror soundtrack.  But it fits the game wonderfully.  You'll jump in your seat more than once, when masked antagonists suddenly appear from the shadows.

The detail in the game's environment is incredible; the author obviously thought of hundreds of things the player might try to do, with just as many hilarious ways to die as there are ingenious ways to win.  At times, the gameplay can be frustrating--BE PREPARED TO DIE A LOT, A WHOLE LOT.  DYING A LOT IS REQUIRED TO FIGURE OUT YOUR ENVIRONMENT, AND IT IS IMPORTANT NOT TO GET FRUSTRATED WITH THAT FACT ABOUT THE GAME.  (In part V, it becomes a downright game mechanic!)  

When you get to part V, you may feel tempted to use a walkthrough, although I would suggest looking up as little as possible.  Just look up the Bible reference and the morse code parts (it was a dick move to include puzzles, which required such solutions... I say this, even though I think this is one of the best and most creative puzzle games I've played in decades).  

The art and graphics are pixelated, reminiscent of VGA Sierra games, like King's Quest I-IV.  There are a varety of sprites to accompany the variety of things you might try as a player; in all, the characters' interactions are hilarious, which compliments the horrific setting.

Seriously, you get four interesting, creative, independently-made games for just ten bucks.  I would advise getting them, and NOT USING A WALKTHROUGH.  Trust me: when you figure out how to survive the killers, all on your own, in any one of these games, you cannot help but leap up and cheer.

24167776.review:
This is a collection of pixelated sandbox horror excursions. Each episode thematically riffs off classic slasher films like Friday the 13th and House of 1,000 Corpses. These episodes are fairly short and meant to be played multiple times. The episodes are connected by a hub world in the form of a movie theatre. 
      
    You have four characters that you can switch between, but only one of them has to survive to win. Occassionally, you'll need two or more survivors to solve puzzles such as opening doors, triggering traps, or procuring items- but these are usually optional tasks. There are various items and interactable objects scattered throughout the levels, some of which are merely "toys" to mess around with, and some which have a practical application. Each chapter is completely open to the player to do as they please, save for a few locked doors and hidden items that require a brief task first. You will have time to explore a little before the killer spawns, but sometimes you can speed this process up by "summoning" it via common horror movie tropes such as having premarital sex. While the game is completely open, there is usually a series of steps that need to be taken to get the good endings.

    As a gamer from the SNES generation, I absolutely loved this game for its Pick-Up-And-Play attitude. If you like retro indie games, there's no reason not to check the game out.

I had a lot of fun figuring each stage out and the wacky mishaps that I typically brought upon myself along the way. I enjoyed the overall theme of horror-comedy, enhanced by the pixelated art style, the music and - again - the trial and error sand-box game play. 

Said trial and error gameplay does mean the game will likely be harder as one begins, but becomes significantly easier as one figures things out, though one puzzle was particularly obscure, which is my only real complaint. Even then I'd say it's a matter of personal preference.

Not particularly lengthy, but it doesn't have to be. It was still very engaging, fun, and still a bit creepy now and again. There are a few minor bugs, but they generally do not get in the way of gameplay and the dev has been fairly good at ironing them out as he hears of them so I have faith they'll eventually be worked out. 

I definitely recommend this. Especially if you enjoyed the original Lakeview Cabin.

23246183.review:
This game is... Something.

Basically, the premise is that you play through rip offs of classic horror movies. LVC 3 apes Friday the 13th, LVC4 apes Texas Chainsaw Massacre, LVC 5 apes Halloween, and the 6th is a combination of Alien and The Thing.

Each level is an open ended adventure puzzle game, essentially, with each one having distinct objectives. For instance, in 3 you are simply trying to ward off the killers without all four of your teenagers (that you control one at a time) dying. In 4, you are searching a truly demented mansion and slaughterhouse for gas so the band you play as can make their next gig. In 5, you try to avoid a Michael Meyers esque killer while summoning monsters that can bring him down.

There's a lot to like with this game. For one, each level is very distinct from the others. The first is probably the most open ended and trial and error one, because it's a very small, confined setting. It's the one that is quite tough to figure out, but once you do, it's pretty rewarding. Plus, there are lots of things you can do in the environment, so it's fun to experiment. While 3 is relatively tame despite the gore, 4 and 5 ramp up the creep factor. Yes, believe it or not, this game actually manages to be pretty disturbing and creepy thanks to its sound design and creative use of visuals. Both 4 and 5 have an extremely macabre and dark feeling to them that 3 simply does not, and it's pretty welcome. 

I will say that certain elements stand out as flawed. For one, the layout of the buildings in 4 is entirely RNG, and it can glitch so that, without giving too much away, you can't continue. This is really annoying, as I've died more than once in that level simply because of the rng. Additionally, 5 is one I simply needed a guide for. Originally, I felt bad, but after actually seeing the solution, I don't, because it's very obtuse. Fun and macabre, but very, very obtuse.

Still, this is worth checking out for people who love old horror films and are in the mood for something different. It's definitely not a game that holds your hand, and you may need a guide every now and then, but the wonderful mixture of humor and truly disturbing content as well as the open ended gameplay make this stand out as a real gem. I'm looking forward to the sequel, and hope that the creator refines it even more to make an even better game than this one.

22856670.review:
This is a completely new review. My last one only told of my experience and nothing about the game mechanics. First off, you control 1 of 4 teenagers at any given time that can be cycled through at will. There are different ones in the 4 episodes that come with Lakeview Cabin Collection, although Cabin 6 is in beta currently, you can still play it. Each "movie" is set in a different setting with (obviously) different characters and maniacal serial killers. Some of them even have multiple killers... I'm looking at you Cabin 4...

The game really builds a sense of dread as you take down the killer with one blast and you approach him to see if he's dead he'll inevitably pop up, bash you, take your weapon and murder you. From that, you'll be so shook up, while you may have 3 more characters to formulate a plan, they will likely all perish in a rather gory fashion until you wise up and search for more supplies hidden and use them to your advantage with your surroundings. 

The game does not shy away from dark and gory subject matter either as a lot of my screenshots can attest. All in all, it keeps the surprises coming. It consistently will make you jump. You know the little pixellated killer may pop out or is just on the other side of the door, your heart rate won't care, it will climb. You will get panicked. Then you'll die and try again. It's a very fun game that has basic puzzles you uncover through exploration and using the tools at hand rather logically. 

Sound also plays a major role. You may find certain items by listening when you throw something... is that a sock that sounds metallic when thrown? Must be something inside... Is the music ratcheting up when nearing a door? That psychopath may be ready to pounce out... just maybe... 

It's impressive what a one-man team was able to produce on this. The level of detail for pixel graphics and the sound is impressive. Wind chimes blow in the breeze. There's a day/night cycle with some light weather effects. I couldn't recommend it more.

Lakeview Cabin Collection is a parody of classic slasher  movies, obviously directly inspired from Friday the 13th (There is actually a Friday the 13th Easter Egg within the first chapter). Within the first chapter, your protagonists include a group of 4, "racially diverse" friends... and your dogge. 

The game mechanics are a bit tricky at first, I wont lie. However, once you get the hang of it, it's like 2nd nature. Trying not to fall and break your characters legs is another challenge if your not so careful, like me. 
It is quite difficult to survive the experience with all characters still alive but not impossible.

The ultimate aim of the game is to spend 2 days searching through the area, obtaining items and setting up traps and hiding your dogge to survive against the murderers that attack on your second night. I dont want to give away too much of the rest of the chapters, it really is worth checking out yourself.

Coming out in this episodic fashion, which is great because by the time it takes for them to release a new chapter you should hopefully have gotten through the previous one. 

In conclusion its a great game, and definitely woth the cost. (Much better than the actual Friday the 13th Games, hopefully the new game redeems all of that).

22348723.review:
A Splendid Horror Homage 

Lakeview Cabin makes me jump, but not in the cheap way so many other horror games seem to.  It does it In the proper way, using atmosphere, timing and many of the tricks from the well-thumbed slasher film rulebook. The game uses sound and score superbly in this regard, the sudden cries of the crows seem filled with portent, the creak of a rafter, a door opening somewhere off screen. It all helps build the tension beautifully.  The charm of the chunky sprites and backgrounds lend extra heft to the stabs of panic inducing action, too. The cute pixel characters offset nicely against the horrific situations. 

For me, each episode of Lakeview gets better with every attempt. While the challenge of getting one character to the end of an episode without significant blood loss would probably not be enough to keep me playing, it is the detail in the design of each distinct episode and the individual stories that have me returning for more. All the episodes are challenging and amusing in their own macabre ways, each having more emphasis on certain of Lakeview's gameplay elements. If I had to pick a favourite it'd be the puzzle heavy Episode 5. The supernatural elements are clevery used and the suburban setting is perfect, right down to the kid brother's toy laser gun.

My only criticism is one that could possibly be chalked up to my own inferior grey matter. I simply cannot fathom what to do in episode 4. It's great fun to play but invariably I end up with every character reduced to a fine pixel paste within ten minutes and not the foggiest glimmer of a clue about how to progress on the next attempt. As far as I can tell the aim is simply to be suddenly butchered in the most amusing way possible. 

As an homage to 70's and 80's horror and slasher films as well as classic adventure/puzzle games they don't come much better than this one.  Looking forward to Episode 6!

这是一款在国内乃至国外都比较冷门的游戏（哈哈，我就喜欢冷门的游戏）
我的第一个游戏就是这个，还是一个老美同学推荐的，B级恐怖片风格的横版像素游戏
游戏名翻译过来就是《湖边小屋》，可是当你玩了游戏后就会发现：“这TM哪里有湖？！”
游戏是一个flash小游戏的续作，剧情很复杂，要靠自己理解，据我分析大概是：一家人在一个湖边有一个小木屋，生活的很幸福。妻子怀着一个孩子，丈夫维持这个家的生计。可是一天两夫妻发生了争执，丈夫失手杀了妻子，于是妻子和还未出生的孩子怀着怨念诅咒了这个湖边小屋，从此这个湖变成了人间地狱......
游戏是按章节发行，总共6章——
1章：flash小游戏，上网可以找到
番外（偏离主线）：下水道里有一个杀人狂，四个主角与他进行对抗
3章：四个年轻人在湖边小屋游玩，不巧遇到了已经精神失常的丈夫和变成女鬼的妻子[spoiler]这个章节让角色都脱光衣服到床上有惊喜（滑稽[/spoiler]
4章：一个乐队开车经过湖边小屋，不料车在屋子前熄火了，四人决定去小屋里寻求帮助......
5章：湖边小屋已不复存在，取而代之的是一个新的街区，这个街区也将发生不幸（这一章改编自1978年经典恐怖电影<月光光心慌慌>）
6章（最离谱的一章）：地球已经毁灭（什么鬼啊喂），一些幸存者住在宇宙空间站里，可是一群外星生物入侵了空间站（致敬<异形>的一章）
[spoiler]隐藏关卡第2章：重新讲述了湖边小屋的由来（通关所有章节可解锁）[/spoiler]
总之还不错的一款游戏，喜欢像素和恐怖类型的同学不要错过~
P.S.此游戏没有中文，连补丁也没有，英语不好的谨慎入手，不然读不懂剧情

21882081.review:
[h1]  EXPRESSO REVIEW [/h1] 
This 1980’s serial killer slasher is a totally rad gore-fest of a game, but prepare to be stumped as it's definitely not an easy romp through the corpse filled wonderland.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
- Pixelated, blood-soaked mayhem!
- A multitude of methods for killing those pesky serial killers, sooo many *options* :-D
- Replayablilty
- The game does not hold your hand

[h1]CONS[/h1]
- Some parts can leave you scratching your head for hours
- It's not quite apparent what to do next, leading to lots of do-overs
- Could be too frustrating for those who prefer a straightforward gameplay

[h1]THE FRENCH PRESSED LONG REVIEW[/h1]

[h1]FIRST MINUTES[/h1]

I feel like this review needs an old horror movie treatment; Something extra scary with a creaky old voice narrating. "Shrouded in a dense fog with the voices of the despaired dead arising, the tainted blood of B-horror movies oozes out of a computer monitor..."  Yep.  I see the bloody puddles under my chair.  Next to a dirty pair of socks.  Arrgh, my *last* good dirty pair of socks too.  Time to fire up some jump scares and spoopy spoops.

I skinny dipped into the game that night -  a blind playthrough.  Okay,  *truthfully* I would likely leave my underwear on ( modesty be damned ), but you get the idea.  What do you think I discovered?  Why, nothing less than a schizo-spasmic pixelated horror-fest of episodic blood-spattered evil!   And there were pugs too -little ones, running around the screen. Oh, the humanity!

You start outside of a movie theatre in the dead of night, with the disturbing sounds of a dangerous city all around.  Move forward, pick up a few items, search around a bit, and you’ll find the movie theatre dead ahead with three feature films on hand.  These are the episodes you’ll be playing. You can pick any one of them in any order.  I started out with the first door I saw, episode III,  which featured a summer camp terrorized by some rather quick footed serial killers a la "Friday the 13th". Looking at my surroundings I realized I am playing as a group of people, clicking back and forth between them as I would a hand of cards.  So, I can be a teen dude-stud or the cute girl next door.  I searched around and looked inside a building to find a...bedroom.

Right away, I was able to make myself naked on a bed in a cabin having sex with a girl with the sole intention of seeing if I could.  Boom-shocka-locka, it worked!  And that was actually part of the game!  I swear those dudes were digitally man-scaped too.  That's the kind of game Lakeview Cabin Collection is: an ode to teen slasher movies with all the intrinsically nasty bits included.

[h1]GAMEPLAY & STORY[/h1]

What is this ode to cinema-du-slash all about?  A survival horror zombie-fest with robo-dinosaurs, perhaps? Pfft.  Puh-lease.  This game is about surviving the nights of murdering crazies and killing them off while unlocking the secrets of the episode.  I think.  In any case: kill or die, that much is apparent.  I began to hunt for clues, take things apart, and solve some puzzles without much idea of what was going on or why.  Oddly, it's a bit like an adventure game in this way with using combinations of items, unlocking hidden things in the background, trying out items on the killers, etc.  And also, there is a significant strategy in attacking the baddies at night.  Yet, it's quite open in design.  Unlike many games, you don't need to perform an action in an *exact* way in order to progress...and for that I am incredibly happy.  Your option list is extremely varied.  A little too varied, even.  Sort of like trying to choose what to eat at a buffet with lots of goodies at the bar.  There are a ton of different ways to approach those killers: motorcycle of death, beer can, gas container, oven fire, lamp oil, hammer, musical instrument, teddy bear, etc.  Granted, some of those items won't do a single thing.  You'll find quite a bit of trial and error in the gameplay.  Which again, may or may not irritate the player into a game rage.  To complete an episode you must kill all the killers. So, best not to goof off *too* much before you end up a pixelated stain on the floor.

What becomes immediately apparent is that you are going to die. Repeatedly.  Over and over and over and over and...well, over.  I can see how that can turn some folks off.  There is only so much you can take of planning a stage, setting up all the right parts, doing all the correct actions, trying your best, and seeing it all fall apart when a slasher is too resilient and kills every last one of your group. For that, I do chalk this game up as - NOT EASY.  Prepare to sink some hours in.

After finishing episode III, I popped into episode IV.  And by that, I mean I died non-stop for a very long time.  This episode is about an all-girl rock band stuck in a compound with a family of serial killers that are simply waiting to be discovered.  Unlike before, you are running to the killers instead of running away as they sneak up.  You're going to be exploring what seems like an endless series of rooms filled to the brim with bloody, twisted murdering nightmare scenes.  It's harrowing to say the least and you get slashed at every few seconds.  But you *do* get to fight back.  One time I ended up soaking my whole screen in red.  Honestly, even after an hour of playing this level I felt like I barely scratched the surface.  It was amazing fun, and a challenge I thoroughly enjoyed, but I was pretty damned horrible at even trying to win this level.  I had to stop and try out episode V.  I knew when I was out of my league.

Now, episode V is much slower.  More along the lines of episode III and I felt like I could tackle it better. Well, at least in the beginning I thought I could.  This episode was hiding more from me than the others.  It's set in - let's say 1987 - you once again are a group of teens and there is a ethereal serial killer involved along with a sort of purgatory of spirits where your soul goes to when you die. You have to figure out what needs to happen when your soul arrives there both before and after you are resurrected - with very cryptic hints.  The puzzles involved are more elusive than in episode III, and the order in which you complete them is slightly more important to finish the episode.  Not that it's linear in that way, I solved several of the puzzles completely out of order, but there is a set of actions that has to be figured out in order to complete the grand puzzle involved.  It's not easy.  Not at all.  And I hate to admit it, but I had to look up a guide just to move on  after getting stuck for hours.   There were secret numbers and codes involved, some hidden in a way that I honestly would NEVER have guessed.  Even looking at someone's guide for hints when I got stuck, I *still* think it was quite hard.  And the cartridge video game...OMG the video game...that took me ages to figure out on my own until I accidentally got it with a naked girl ending. Too bad that wasn't the end!  It was just a small part of a grander series of puzzles to complete.  I'd be spoiling it to tell you any more, but once you attack the killer with all the evil at hand, you will get that euphoric "I BEAT IT!" feeling we all know and love.  Now, I want to go back to episode IV.  And I have.  Still trying as a matter of fact.  The chainsaw dude is just insanely hard to kill for me and I have a feeling there are a lot more people hidden in that house.

[h1]FINAL THOUGHTS[/h1]

Come into this game with an open mind about surviving in a horror movie, *lots* of patience, and knowing full well you will die repeatedly.  Perhaps even killed by stepping on farm tools!  It's not an easy game to complete and you will likely get stumped - maybe a lot.  Be careful you don't get chipped away in a wood chipper when you are not looking! [b]8.5/10[/b].

Disclaimer: A review key was provided by the developer.

20283501.review: A solidly executed, simple concept with heaps and heaps of polish.  It plays well, looks great, the tone feels spot on for slasher tropes, and (the 2nd chapter especially): it keeps you tense without being obnoxious.  You will not win the first or tenth round, but you will keep learning and correcting, retinkering a plan until it works. Brute force rarely works and when it does, you have paid for it dearly.  The attention to detail in this game exceeds my expectation.  Two aspects I feel the developer did exceptionally well with are sound (particularly with auditory cues) and color (lighting and adherence to the appropriate color scheme.)  Compare the Friday 13th chapter to the Texas chainsaw massacre dizyingly sickening, washed out color scheme, for example.  Also, notice the transition of artificial light in the context of passing day/night.  These (both sound and color), I think are crucial components to recreating the tone and atmosphere of a slasher movie, and the developer executed it well.

19543422.review:
The Lakeview Cabin Collection is a surivival horror action puzzle game for STEAM. 

Before I talk about what I disliked about it, let me talk about what I enjoyed. It covers several genres of horror that I grew up with, from the killers, to the scenes and settings. The nostalgila factor alone already makes this game pretty good. 

I like the art, it's retro, while still having it's own style and being able to separate itself from all the games that use the entire concept of retro art it's whole selling point. 

The game also manages to be able to tell a story in a very basic manner without needing to have any sort of text. And I respect that. They did it in a much better way then Scott could ever hope to do with Five Nights At Freddies. 

Now for the bad. To begin with, the controls are kind of wonky, it's going to take you awhile to get used to the very minimalistic controls they use. The game uses 'context senestive' icons to let you know when you can perform an action, but it isn't always clear what it is or what it's used for. 

The hit detection in this game is terrible. 9 out of 10 times, an enemy will hit me before I even get remotely close to it, but the game, for whatever reason, seems to think I need to be right on top of an enemy to attack it. There's hard and then there's poor programming and this game could use a better combat system. At least give players the same attack reach the enemies do, that's only fair.

While the game advertises itself as a 'sandbox' game, the reality is, each "feature" feels like the developers had a very specific idea on how the features should be solved. There's a lot of junk laying around, but a large majority of it simply doesn't feel useful in any sense. 

It's kind of like Lemmings. The developers had a very specific idea on how every puzzle should be solved and while some people managed to avoid it, luck out and still win a stage, many others were left scratching their heads.

Finally, the puzzles in the game are simply atrocious. Many of them, you won't understand what's going on unless you watch or read some sort of guide. It suffers from the same 90's adventure point and click game issues, where nonsensical actions result in a reaction that helps you. From banging a lady on a bed to find a key, to pooping in a toilet to drop a stuffed bear, the end result is, what were they thinking?

Here's the thing, I appreciate the game and the concept of it. There's a lot of it I actually do like, but so much of it has made me so frustrated that I had to stop playing. The developers clearly workd hard on this product, but a lot of times the direction and mechanics feel really off. 

At the time of writing this, I could have gotten a refund, but I decided not to. But unless you have a great mind of super obscure puzzles, unfair mechanics and bad hit detection, most of you would be better left off not buying this game. I suggest you play the FREE Lakeview Cabin game first, it's a java based game and will show you everything you need to see to decide to buy the game or not.

19487636.review:
Huge fun! With surprising depth.

A silly, endlessly replayable game that, deceptively, seems like a goofy bit of fun but, gradually, lures you into a narrative that tentacle-like spreads between chapters and gets under your skin.

Somehow bridging the gap between the original Mario Bros arcade game (fondly remembered as a sub-game in Mario 3) and the logic problems of a point-and-click adventure, though occasionally the solutions are bafflingly obscure and can involve a bit of outside reading! Which, to me, is an interesting touch, though something of a cop out...

Nevertheless, every else about this game is utterly joyous, the retro graphics are smart and witty, the sound design shocking, disgusting, funny, the music cues are pitch perfect, and the gameplay is straight-forward and so much fun.

Even more entertaining though, is introducing friends to this game, handing them the controls for the first (though due to the wider narrative it's named Lakeview Cabin III here) chapter and watching them figure things out, then shriek in terror and howl with laughter.

18997913.review:
Lakeview Cabin Collection is a parody of various horror movies of 70's and 80's. Here, you get a band of typical horror protagonists at your hands, and your goal is to make them survive against various maniacs and hazards.

The biggest hazard will actually be you. Have you always wondered why all these slasher movie heroes are so dumb? Why do they always split up? Why do they never watch where they go? Why don't they just bash the maniac with that handy candlestick right next to them? Why don't they stuff him into the grinder so he never rises up again?

Well, you're going to make all the stupid decisions a slasher movie protagonist ever made, and lead your characters to their bloody but hilarious demise. After a few bad endings, you will manage to get at least some of the heroes to survive the attack and put the monsters to rest...

Only to fail spectaculary in the next chapter! I won't spoil it for you, but the gameplay changes drastically, even though all the mechanics are the same. And then the third chapter is going to surprise you even more, going from slashers to mystery thriller territory.

The graphics may look simplistic, but there are a lot of nice touches like the sun flickering in the lake or an oscillating weather vane. Overall cartoony art style plays greatly for the whole parody thing, sometimes you just can't help but laugh (maybe with some hysteria notes) watching a chibi-proportioned maniac with an axe closing in on your poor hero. Even more hilarious when overly dramatical high-pitched cello music starts playing and scare chords empathize his blows.

All in all, Lakeview Cabin Collection is a great game, which manages not only to capture the feel of the old horrors, but does it in just right proportions and, most of all, has a solid, interesting and challenging gameplay.

As of today, this game has roughly 12k owners according to Steamspy. It definitely deserves more attention!

18853134.review:
Я думаю, что многие из нас смотрели классические slasher фильмы.  И были моменты, когда мы кричали на героев фильма, потому что они тупили, ходили по - одному, совершали глупые поступки. Конечно, если бы мы там были в этом лагере или в этом страшном лесу, мы бы не совершали глупых действий, не ходили бы по – одному, да вообще быстро бы справились с маньяком.  Ну и вот наконец-то появился вызов нам в лице LAKEVIEW CABIN COLLECTION –комедийная хоррор игра, в которой ты сам становишься героем фильма ужасов. Первая часть игры относит нас в пародию на ,,Пятницу – 13,, ну или ,,Спящий Лагерь,, (кстати отличный slasher). Вы берете на себя управление 4 персонажей. Управляя своим персонажем, вы можете делать много веселых вещей: выпить, покурить, искупаться, покататься на канатной дороге, ну или что-то  более эротического содержания. При нажатии пробела, вы можете переключаться на следующего героя. Вскоре, появится убийца, и тогда игра из веселой превратиться стратегическую головоломку, в которой вам нужно перехитрить и уничтожить своего врага, в данном случае убийцу. Веселье заключается в том, что игра дает вам много вариантов развития сюжета, вы сами расставляете ловушки, сами должны понять как и что тут работает и поверьте это будет смешно.  Это сложный процесс, и даже тогда, когда вы знаете, что вы сделали, что куда расставили и у вас все готово, то обязательно, что то пойдет по другому пути, мне например мешала собака, то наступлю на грабли, то маньяк выйдет с другой стороны. Даже когда я уже научился все просчитывать и убивал одного убийцу, то я и терял 1-2 своих напарников. В связи с этим, игра может показаться вам  очень сложной. 
Интересно, что игра остается страшной и пугающей, но также смешной и веселой одновременно. Игра держит в напряжении своей музыкой и прекрасными звуковыми эффектами, которые в некоторые моменты по-настоящему пугают, также отличная озвучка окружающей среды.
Местность и окружение тоже выглядит отлично, вы можете наблюдать кишки и отрубленные головы на домах, или разрубленные тела своих товарищей, различные надписи, отсылки к старым добрым фильмам ужасов, пасхалочки, все шикарно. А то чувство, когда ты играешь за персонажа, хочешь переключиться на другого, и видишь, что он уже мертв и понимаешь, что опять все пошло не по плану. 
LAKEVIEW CABIN COLLECTION является одним из наиболее интригующих игр, которые я играл в последнее время.  Это определенно игра не для всех, у вас должно быть желание экспериментировать, делать все снова и снова, придумывать что то новое или наоборот повторяться, вымерять, рассчитывать, ну и вы должны иметь хоть какие то знания о классических фильмах ужасов. 
Кстати пройдя первую главу, вы можете попробовать себя в ней снова, только сражаясь с армией зомбей в черно-белом цвете (Ночь Живых Мертвецов, Озеро Зомби) привет Фульчи и Ромеро.
А вот вторая глава игры пародирует ,, Техасскую Резню Бензопилой,, причем очень адово пародирует. Тут есть все, автобус с друзьями, маньяк с бензопилой в маске свинья, лезбиянки копро-некрофилки, каннибалы, два гомосексуалиста извращенца, крыса людоед, беременная женщина, которая родит потом еще одну чупакабру. Вообщем жесть и кровищаааааа….. Вторая глава также шикарна.
И недавно вышла 3 глава, похожая на фильм ,,Хеллоуин,, (хотя похож только дом маньяка). В остальном там тоже множество пародий и отсылок, но уже меньше экшена, в 3 главе нам дают больше подумать и поиграться с параллельными мирами. 
P.S. Кстати как я понял каждая глава связанна между собой. 
Ждем новую главу, надеемся, что она не будет хуже, а только лучше !!!
Игру советую брать по скидке, хотя и 300р не пожалел на ее покупку, так как наиграл в нее более 30 часов.

18781185.review:
Lakeview Cabin es de esos juegos casuales que te dan una grata sorpresa. Esperaba encontrar un juego de partidas rápidas, para ratos muertos, y lo he encontrado. Mis protagonistas acaban igual de muertos que los ratos pero ¿no es acaso una simulación de películas de terror ochenteras? ¿Y qué pasaba con los protagonistas de esas pelis? Que morían... pues eso.

Se trata de un juego con gráficos pixelados y vista lateral donde cada capítulo replica una película 'slasher' distinta. El capítulo III es la clásica historia de la pandilla que va a una cabaña del bosque al estilo Viernes 13. El IV es la historia de unas chicas que se quedan sin gasolina a las puertas de un matadero como en la Matanza de Texas. Y el V, que se estrenó ahora por Halloween, es de estética urbana y con una historia de fantasmas. Los capítulos se escogen entrando en la sala de cine donde los proyectan.

Cada capítulo se compone de un escenario relativamente pequeño con un montón de objetos. Es sorprendente, para lo básico que es el control, la de movidas que se pueden hacer. Porque realmente usas el mando para moverte y luego dos botones: uno para coger/soltar cosas y otro para lanzarlas o usarlas, dependiendo el objeto. Ese mismo botón de lanzar sirve para actuar con cosas del escenario (camas, arcones, puertas). 

Pero con un planteamiento tan simple puedes hacer de todo, incluyendo cosas tan cafres y divertidas como una orgía pixelada (en serio, desnuda a varios personajes y mételos en la misma cama ¡es un logro!) o convertirte tú mismo en el psicópata y acabar a machetazos con tus compañeros de reparto. El plan oficial, claro, es matar al asesino antes de que acabe contigo. Dependiendo el capítulo habrá que hacer unas cosas u otras. La verdad es que sin una guía me parece muy difícil, sobre todo el capítulo V (es el más extraño para mi gusto). Aún así es divertido intentar completar el juego usando cosas y viendo que pasa. A veces te llevas sorpresas.

En cada partida el malo aparece cuando le da la gana y donde quiere. También cambian algunas cosas de sitio, con lo que se favorece la aleatoriedad. 

Como digo se trata de un juego para ratos muertos. Divertido, bien hecho, fácil de manejar pero difícil de superar. 

Aparte de los tres capítulos que ya trae disponibles al parecer el autor ha prometido un cuarto que se añadirá de forma gratuita, así que nos queda sangre para rato.

¿Puntos negativos? Por culpa de la estética pixelada a veces cuesta saber que es cada objeto hasta que lo usas. La primera vez que pillé un mechero le prendí fuego a una cama y todo lo que había en ella sin querer. Y hasta que me di cuenta de que un recuadro en la pared era una pistola de bengalas en una vitrina pasaron varias partidas... Otra cosa es lo que he comentado: sin un guía a mí hay cosas que ni se me ocurriría hacer en el capítulo V, porque no acabo de verle la lógica.

Por lo demás se trata de un juego entetenido que demuestra que una buena idea, bien llevada, no requiere grandes recursos técnicos para funcionar.
