18748516.review: A really enjoyable tribute to old slasher films. Four "episodes" (plus a hub area), each based on a classic horror franchise (Friday the 13th, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, ect). You are given control of four characters with the goal being not getting killed. How you go about doing so is up to you. Will you go mano a mano with the killers? (bad Idea) Will you set up traps and try to lure them in? Will you just hide under a bed, cry, and hope they don't find you? There's a lot of trial and error involved and you'll be restarting episodes from scratch every time you fail, but there's a real sense of accomplishment when a plan finally works and you make it through. This is an overlooked gem and is perfect for the Halloween season or if you just want some late-night bloody fun.

18734765.review:
There haven't really been a lot of slasher-inspired games thus far, something that Until Dawn will hopefully change. It's strange, too, because they constitute such a major part of horror in cinema, and have all the components of a worthwhile game. Lakeview Cabin Collection puts those components on display in the best way possible, by letting you combine them as you like. And the result is surprisingly addictive.

"Lakeview Cabin" is the title of an in-universe series of horror movies, centered around the titular cursed lake. The game chucks you right onto the street outside the theater, which you can enter to select a movie to enjoy. You can also huck boxes, beat up hobos, plunge toilets, eat popcorn, and harass the cinema staff. It's a great introduction to the ridiculous sandbox nature of the game. On a controller, A lifts and drops things, X throws, shoots, eats, or uses, B enters doorways, and Y lets you switch between controllable characters (4 to a scene). And yes, those commands work on almost every single thing in the game, including people. And their parts.

At this time, LCC contains two episodes, III and IV. V and VI are promised for the future, but I will say up front that the current two are worth the price of admission alone. Episode III is a perfect send-up of Friday the 13th, giving you control of four teens partying on an island. There are beers to drink, bongs to hit, clothes to strip, and fully-functional beds. When night falls, a strange and relentless killer may show up, which you need to puzzle out a way to defeat. It's harder than it sounds because (A) the killer can take a LOT of punishment, and (B) certain elements of the episode are randomized. Your shotgun may not be loaded, or the tools might be hidden in another cabin. The killer also approaches from where you'll least expect him. I'm not kidding, either. If you camp out with weapons, he'll lay low, so you actually have to do idiot horror movie things to draw him out. Which you're going to do anyway, because interacting with the chaotic, bloody world is irresistably fun.

If episode III is an homage to Friday the 13th, episode IV is an amazing recreation of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre. Your band is stuck on the grounds of the Lakeview Slaughterhouse, and you'll have to do plenty of slaughtering to escape. The creator of LCC listened to feedback about episode III being to puzzley, so IV is far more focused on action. There are tons of freaks and killers to fight and trick as you find your way through their house of horrors, the layout of which is randomized every time you play. However, what really got me about IV was how perfectly it apes the look of TCM, even in pixel form. The whole episode looks fucking gross, with clashing colors, washed-out exteriors, equal helpings of gore and disturbing imagery, and some truly messed-up foes.

Despite how entertaining getting your characters high and knocking them into a wood chipper is, Lakeview Cabin Collection still manages to be genuinely scary. Waiting for the killer at the lake or getting spotted by a psycho in the slaughterhouse comes with a perfect audio stinger and a rush of adrenaline as you scramble to respond. The enemies are appropriately deadly and require careful planning to overcome, so there's always an air of dread to encounters. Admittedly, there's not much depth to the antagonists, and that's one place the game could really stand to improve. They just beat on you, or grab weapons and beat on you. Seeing them set traps or kidnap characters would add some variety, but what's there now certainly doesn't get in the way of the fun. And it's such a rare thing, to have a game that's fun and scary in equal measure. Appropriate, too, since that's how the best slasher films are.

'Lakeview Cabin Collection' is an hilarious homage to the classic teen horror genre of the 80's that manages to simultaneously creep me out and make me chuckle....or at least it did for about the first 15 minutes. Once the mystique of witnessing an uncensored drunken orgy get brutally interrupted by a neotenous, axe wielding psychopath wore off, I started to realize how terribly this game is designed.

But even design aside, I could forgive the needlessly convoluted item system, and I could forgive the wonky controls and questionable art style (even by pixel art standards). The real issue with this game is that it is presented as a "sandbox" experience...but there's just not all that much to do. Think Scribblenauts, but without any kind of creative canvas at your disposal. You're basically just running around as long as you can, picking up rakes and turning wood chippers off and on...and throwing that red-headed, open-shirted manwhore into it for sleeping with your girlfriend....until the maniac comes to kill you. 

And don't even bother with Lakeview Cabin IV. It is beyond monotenous. It's just a "mouse-in-a-maze" type of situation. By the time I started mapping out a path through that slaughterhouse, I was very, very tired of playing already.

I can't really recommend it, honestly. Save that ten dollars and buy some delicious nuts and berries or something. I wish I could have.

[h1] Ich habe eigentlich einen Entspannten Urlaub erwartet, doch was ich bekam war mehr Survival als Entspannung. [/h1]

Lakeview Cabin Collection ist eines der interessantesten (Horror-)Survivalgames die ich seit langem gespielt habe. 
Nicht nur das, das Spiel einige Klassische Horrorfilme Parodiert, sondern auch das Menü des Spiels ist gut umgesetzt.

Beim Starten des Spiels finden wir uns in einem Kino wieder, in dem wir die einzelen Level(Episode/Filme) starten können.

Als ich diese Bewertung geschrieben habe, gab es bisher nur Level(Episode/Filme) 3 und 4.

Wir können jederzeit, bzw. solange unsere Charaktere alle noch Leben, zwischen ihnen hin und her wechseln. Es gibt 4 Charaktere zur Auswahl, die sich nur vom Aussehen unterscheiden.
In Sachen interaktion hat das Spiel auch einiges zu bieten, man kann mit allem möglichen interagieren, zb kann man eine Fliegenklatsche aufheben und Fliegen damit schlagen oder man nimmt eine Axt und hackt Türen ein, wie Jack aus Stanley Kubricks Shinning. 

Was interessant wirkt, kann aber auch etwa abflachen, vor allem dadurch, das unter anderem in Episode 3 wirklich vorbereitung von nöten ist. Man sollte davon ausgehen das man das Spiel einige male spielen muss, um zu wissen wie man die Episoden schafft.

Nun zu den Episoden:

[b] Episode 3 - Lakeview Cabin[/b]

4 Freunde sind auf einer kleinen Insel um Urlaub zu machen (oder was man dort sonst so macht)
Nach einiger Zeit kommt ein Killer der sich der Freunde annimmt. Wenn man nicht aufpasst stibrt einer nach dem anderen weg.  Das Ziel ist es den Killer aufzuhalten, in dem Fall, vorher zu töten, bevor er einen töten kann.

Wie schon erwähnt erfordert diese Episode einige vorbereitungszeit, da sie praktisch immer nach dem gleichen Schema abläuft, daher möchte ich auch nicht zu viel schreiben, da man auch noch etwas zum entdecken hat, das macht dieses Spiel nämlich auch sehr aus.

[b] Episode 4 - Curse of the Lake [/b]

Einer 4 Köpfigen Band ist das Benzin auf dem Weg zu einem Konzert oder auf dem Weg von einem Konzert nach Hause, ausgegangen. Nun geht es darum 4 Benzinkanister zu finden. Zu doof nur, wenn der Ort wo man liegen bleibt zwar eine Tankstelle hat, diese aber verlassen und heruntergekommen, die Villa etwas weiter, von Irren bewohnt und die Schlachterrei daneben auch nicht gerade einladend ist. 

Diese Episode ist etwas anders. Während Episode 3 immer nach dem selben Schema abläuft und Vorbereitung braucht, ist Episode 4 immer anders. Bei jedem durchspielen, ändert sich die Anordnung der Räume, sowie die der Benzinkanister (diese allerdings nur leicht)

Nach dem durchspielen einer Episode schaltet man einen Gegenstand frei der im Level steht, wenn man diesen aktiviert, ändert sich etwas im Spiel. Bei Episode 3 wird das Spiel zu einer Art "Night of the Living Dead" und bei Episode 4 werden aus den Irren Bewohnern "Vampire"


Alles in allem muss ich sagen, das ich viel Spaß mit dem Spiel hatte und mich schon auf die 2 letzten Episoden freue. Für Fans von Horrorfilmen eine nette Hommage an einige alte und vielleicht auch einige neue Filme.

Alllerdings wird laut dem Spiel ein Controller empfholen, ob es wirklich verpflichtend ist einen zu haben kann ich leider nicht genau sagen.



[i]Eins weiß ich aber jetzt mit sicherheit. Wenn ich das nächste mal Urlaub in einem Ferienhaus mache, suche ich direkt nach der Schrotflinte und der passenden Munition, nur um sicher zu gehen. [/i]

ตัวเกมมันจะแนวสยองขวัญตลกๆ เกมจะให้เข้าไปอยู่ในหนังสยองขวัญสักเรื่อง แล้วหาทางเอาตัวรอดจาก ฆาตกรต่อเนื่อง โดยจะมีของให้เราใช้อยู่รอบๆตัว โดยรวมผมชอบมาก ทั้งเพลงประกอบทำออกมาเหมือนหนังสมัยก่อน ที่มันชอบมีเสียงอิเล็กโทรทำให้ขนลุกเล่นๆ

17479806.review:
Note: This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer. This is a work in progress review, I will update this review when the other episodes are released. 

Lakeview Cabin 3- Review

Lakeview Cabin Collection took me by surprise once it was released. I played the original flash game and thought the idea was very interesting and had a lot of potential and then I saw that the original developer made a new game, on a bigger scale. 

To begin with the game doesn't hold your hand when you start playing, you have to figure out everything by yourself otherwise you won't get anywhere. 

The gameplay is simple. You take control of four campers who get attacked by serial killers and it's up to you to survive. You can set up traps or you can try and take down the killers with brute force, but it's best to take the cautious approach otherwise you won't survive. 

The audio is really well done and is one of the games best features. The sound effects are awesome and sound a lot like the effects in those very cheesy slasher movies that the game is based of. 

The game is overall really well made apart from a few minor bugs like characters not picking up the thing you want them to pick up. 

Lakeview Cabin 3 is a really great episode and a good start to what seems to be a very promising game. I give Lakeview Cabin 3 a 8.5/10

Lakeview Cabin 4- Review

Lakeview Cabin is the second episode in the Collection.  The first episode took us to a camp site like Friday the 13th, but this time we go to a mansion and try not to get killed by a crazy cannibal family.

Lakeview Cabin 4 changes a lot of gameplay aspects from the first episode. This time you need to find 4 gas canisters to fuel up your car and escape a mansion full of crazy cannibals, but to get them you need to kill a lot of people.  Killing increases your crazy meter which makes the screen go crazy and makes more jump scares appear. Enemies are easier to kill but there's more of them and now there's stealth to avoid an even bigger threat which you can't kill so you will have to be more careful.

This episode is very interesting and it feels fresh which I like a lot. Now for the good. The audio is still really good. The gameplay is very fun and challenging which is a lot of fun. Funny like always and the graphics are awesome. 

But there are a few problems. This episode was really buggy. An enemy hit me through a door which was closed, and of course the same problem where my character wouldn't pick up what I wanted to pick up. The random aspect of the episode is a great way to add replay value, but for people who have a hard time with the game might have more trouble since they can't learn from they're mistakes. 

Overall it's still a very fun game and I can't wait to play Episode 3 or Lakeview Cabin 5 whatever you want to call it. It's worth the full price without a doubt. I give Lakeview Cabin 4 a 7.5/10

Lakeview Cabin 5 - Review

Taking  a detour from the previous play style of the other episodes the third episode of Lakeview Cabin takes more of a puzzle game approach. Lakeview Cabin 5 makes you play as four teenagers again in a place that is taken straight out of Halloween the movie. 

The goal in this episode is quite different. You can't die this time, but you have one goal to figure out how to kill a murderer who is immortal. 

As stated before this takes a more slow paced approach than the other two episodes. This time it's more about puzzle solving than anything. I liked the puzzle solving in this episode and some of the puzzles are incredibly crazy not to mention some of the solutions are absurd, but it's incredibly fun non the less. 

When I began this episode, I loved the retro feel. It felt like Halloween the movie with Nightmare on Elm Street characters. This for me the best looking Lakeview Cabin Episode by far.

Now for the bad and there is a lot this time. The episode is the buggiest episode by far. I had to relaunch the episode several times after finishing one of the puzzles due to the audio cutting out after I finish it. Not to mention the very weird movement of the killer. Sometimes he doesn't attack you at all and just jitters and place. 

In the end I loved Lakeview Cabin Episode 3, because of the puzzle solving aspect. In the end if the bugs weren't there I would say it's the best episode right now. 

If you don't own Lakeview Cabin Collection right now, you just simply need to get it. It's one of the most fun you can have with a horror title. 

Lakeview Cabin 5 gets a 8/10

17142522.review: This game is by far one of the most fantastically crafted and detailed horror games I have ever played. The fact that this game was created by a single person shocks me, for it is so detailed and so perfectly displays all of the horror movie tropes we have come to know and love through the years. To thoroughly enjoy this game you must have an imagination to craft a story for these characters, who are basically blank canvases meant to have a personality crafted for them by the player. There also is a briliantly crafted yet oddloy convoluted story that at this point has not been fully revealed due to the fact that only two episodes have been released thus far, yet if you are a person who is fit and able to search out a hidden backstory within a game will be pleasantly suprised. The gameplay is simple due to the fact that it completely revolves around a pick up and throw mechanic I have not seen in any other two dimensional pixelated indie games, yet it feels like this mechanic should have been used from the start in the horror game genre. The second episode feels like an entirely different game, due to the fact that the creator chose to go with a Texas Chainsaw Massacre approach instead of his usual Friday The 13th feel, but still proves to be as incredibly, if not even more, replayable. What the creator has accomplished thus far is incredible, being that he is a single developer who is somehow able to create a game that I, and many others would consider better than most triple a titles released this year. Few other games had me constantly checking the developers twitter for updates on the games progress, and I dont even have an account on that site. This game is so criminaly underplayed that it makes me sick. If you are a fan of anything horror related, it is a neccesity that you buy this game, and if the creator of this game sees this post, please make me a tester, for never before have I wanted to be involved in a games developement more than I would to have the privalige to help you develope this amazing game.

17079621.review:
Usually, when you hear the phrase Horror Comedy, what is being described is a comedy with the dressings of horror.  Movies like Tucker and Dale vs Evil or Shaun of the Dead aren't so much scary as they are kind of gross or gory sometimes, but the comedy is solid and the movies themselves are excellent.

Lakeview Cabin is a unique example of the genre.  When someone says Lakeview Cabin is Horror Comedy, what they mean is that it epitomizes both separate genres equally.  Lakeview Cabin is tense and freaky and, in general, simply excellent at that Horror trick of making you do something while every part of your body tells you not to, especially considering its crude, pixelly style (or, perhaps, partially because of it).  Your heart will race as you try to execute that last, desperate plan to save your own skin as an immortal serial murderer bares down on you in the dark.  At the same time, the freedom it allows the player in its little sandbox levels, combined with the game's swift, incredibly violent consequences of poor decision making, almost immediately opens up a world of hugely bloody, absurd comedy.  In few other games can you run to pick up a shotgun and blast a monster in the face only to discover it is empty, and the only other nearby object is a small pug which has been wandering the island carefree for days now, and in no other games can you desperately pick up that pug and try to hurl it at your killer's face, only for it to soar into a nearby running woodchipper instead, spraying blood and bits of bone at a hapless friend standing nearby.

The game has a sick and hilarious sense of humor, and, at the same time, is thrilling, tense, and off-puttingly weird.  Is that pregnant redneck trapped in the attic the source of all these slimy, bloodthirsty creatures slithering and snuffling through the walls?  Is that a man-sized, deformed infant careening around the island with a knife?  What are they doing with all these chickens?  What is that thing in the lake, and what did it do to our dog?  What are those two naked twins doing in the bathroom with that dessicated corpse?  These are but a tiny fraction of the worrying questions you'll pose to yourself while playing Lakeview Cabin Collection. 

 If you're at all a fan of weird sandbox titles, 70s grindhouse horror flicks, horror in general, comedy, combinations of the two, solving puzzles, playing games, or being a cool person, you should strongly consider giving this a shot.

17063969.review:
Lakeview Cabin is a well done, clever horror move sandbox. Drawing from various horror films, it let's you deal with the creeps in your own way. So far two of it's episodes are out, and both are fanastic, with a very fun, and creepy feel.

One thing I enjoy immensly, is the freedom to play it as I choose. Do I sacrifice one member of my party to try killing a monster? Do I hide them all and try to figure out some elaborate trap? It's all up to you.

The second chapter is as good as the first, with a huge homage to the Texas Chainsaw Massacre cannibal style films. The creator even used a lovely kind of washed out look for the colors, to give it that 70's camera vibe. 

The value of this game is great, and, with even more episodes coming, I can promise if you love horror, twisted comedy, or are bored of the constant Zombie/Survival games, give this one a try. 

10/10.

16946009.review:
10/10 would zip down a line into a working wood chipper again. 

Ahhh, Lakeview Cabin. I was the lucky winner of this game on one of the steam groups I belong to, and I was pleasantly surprised with the creepy pixelated experience. 

Really, the game page says it all:

”Relive the horror movies of the 70's and 80's by answering the question: What would you do if you found yourself in a slasher film?”

And that’s exactly what the game is: A perfect, pixelated representation of your typical horror movie of the 80’s. There you have the girls with their lovely hair, and the boys with their handsome beards, and the creepy lake, and the cabins, and the creepy nude stalker…


Wait, what? o.O

The game is a horror/comedy/parody/adventure type of game. Your goal? To prepare yourself to survive the creepy, murdering monster as long as possible. Or, you know, you could just hide forever.

There are several characters for you to deal with, and switching between them is super easy. 
You get to explore the cabins, find items to aid you with surviving, places to hide, and weapons to use against the horrors of the night. Whenever you get hurt, you actually… get hurt. As in, you miss a leg and you’ll be hopping down that pixelated grass on one leg while bleeding off. the game spares no expenses in the pixelated gore.

You can also kill yourself, kill others, and promptly die when you’re the only one left to face the evil from the lake. There’s more than one way to kill or be killed, and exploring them all is as fun as playing the game as you should be. :) 
And you know what’s more satisfactory than surviving? Not giving the monster the chance to kill you all off, by doing it yourself first. :P

The game is mostly funny to play, but it also, despite being just pixels, manages to be sufficiently creepy as to unnerve you.  The replayability is fairly decent, as you can just replay it to see how many different ways you find to survive, whether you can kill the monster at all, and how long you can last. 

If you’re into a bit of pixelated parody horror, give this one a try! Be warned, though: If you want to play this as it’s intended (as opposed to killing everyone yourself, actually laying traps out for the evil thing), be prepared to be a bit frustrated at the time constraints until you get the hang of what to do.

Looking forward to future episodes!

My favorite game in recent memory. Seamlessly blends the beautifully-nostalgic properties of Maniac Mansion with the old NES Friday the 13th game, in a sandbox-style engine.

There's *much* more to it than that, of course; I'm merely paraphrasing. The music is absolutely fantastic (as are the sound effects), and even the hub world has an interesting mystery to discover. But seriously, I cannot stress enough just how amazing the atmosphere is in this game.

Needless to say, as a huge fan of old NES horror games, and old newgrounds-esque flash games alike, this game is right up my alley. I cannot wait for the new episodes! 10/10

16382920.review:
[h1]【ゲーム内容】[/h1]
簡単に説明すると「ドット絵で描かれたアメリカンチックな世界観で
4人のキャラクターを操り、襲い掛かってくる殺人鬼や化け物を
道具や武器、器具等を用いて倒す」といった内容である。

操作方法は左右キーで移動でき、上キーで部屋に入ったり隠れたりできる。
(ドアの前で上キー長押しで外の様子を見れる)
ｚキーで物を持てて、持った後にｘキーで色々なアクションを起こせる。
またスペースキーでキャラを交代できる。

エピソード(ステージ)数は隠しを含めて現在5つ。
[u]エピソード毎にクリア目標が違うので注意！[/u]

[h1]【Lakeview cabin Ⅲ】[/h1]
湖の真ん中にあるキャンプ場が舞台。
道具や仕掛けがまんべんなく設置されており、
東西端からほぼ安地の湖の中に入ることが出来る。
乗り物が多く、遠距離武器が少ない。

[b]【難易度　★★★★☆】[/b]
[u][b]とにかく敵が強い。尋常でないほど強い。[/b][/u]
恐らく初見では「だれ一人…倒せませんでした。(Syamu並の感想)」となるのが
当たり前なので、まずは色々探ったりアイテムを使ってみよう。
そうすればこれは敵の動きを止められる、こうすれば追跡を逃れられると
クリアへの糸口が見つかるかもしれない。

[b]【恐怖度　★★★★☆】[/b]
敵襲撃前はちょっとした脅かし要素だけ。
物が動いたり、色々なマークを描いたり。[strike](かわいい)[/strike]
だが、襲撃時が恐ろしい。
敵に見つかった時のBGM、攻撃を受けたときのSE、死体の扱い方等
慣れない内は本当に恐怖そのもの。
また襲撃前にあることが起きるため、より一層焦って恐怖を感じてしまう。

[b]【豆知識】[/b]
・発電小屋の近くから背景をよく見ると
　Lakeview cabin Ⅳの舞台が見える。
・コンテナ部屋の２階の床を直さない限り、そこが安全地帯になる。


[h1]【Lakeview cabin Ⅳ】[/h1]
湖のほとりにあるお屋敷+屠殺場が舞台。
初期物資が少なく、
また[u][b]初見殺しトラップが多く仕掛けられている。[/b][/u]
隠し部屋もあったりする。動物の楽園。敵が多い。

[b]【難易度　★★☆☆☆～★★★★☆】[/b]
このエピソードでは
[u]ほとんどの部屋や道具、トラップがランダムで設置[/u]されており、
安定したクリアは難しい。
[spoiler]また[u]一度見つかると警報を鳴らされ、
無敵の特殊部隊が各部屋をうろつく[/u]ようになる。[/spoiler]
運によって難易度は変わるが、
結局のところ初見殺しには変わりはない。
攻略のヒントとしては、
[u][b]部屋の中をよく確認することがとても大事[/b][/u]。(屠殺場では必須)
前作と比べて敵が弱体化してるので、強引に突破するのも一つの作戦だ。

[b]【恐怖度　★★★☆☆】[/b]
今作にはSAN値機能が追加されており、敵にダメージを与えるほど
画面が変化したり、幻覚や幻聴が起こるようになる。
敵に見つかった時の恐怖のBGMはなくなったが、
このSAN値によって引き起こされる怪奇現象が怖い。
ちなみにSAN値は外に出れば自動で回復する。
あとネズミちゃんも驚かしてくる[strike](カワイイ)[/strike]

[b]【豆知識】[/b]
・屠殺場からお屋敷へとショートカットできる部屋がある。(逆もある。)


[h1]【Lakeview cabin Ⅴ】[/h1]
自分にはあまり合わなかったので箇条書きします。
[list]
[*]アメリカの街が舞台。
[*]謎解きがメイン。(かなり難しくて途中で詰んだ)
[*][spoiler]全滅してもゲームオーバーにならない模様。[/spoiler]
[/list]

[b]【残念なところ】[/b]
・説明が無いため、慣れるのに時間がかかる。
・初見殺しが多い(これがこのゲームの良いところでもあるが…)
・エピソードによってクリアする方法が違うため、思考錯誤して探さないといけない。
　→全体的に説明不足な気がした。

殺人鬼をおちょくったり、アイテムの使い方を調べたりと
個人的にとてもオススメできるゲームです！

15527986.review:
Very clever "sandbox" pixel game.
I have played for over an hour and managed to kill no one except myself and my friends.  At first it was on purpose; once I started actually trying to trap and lure the killer then I started to see the potential that this game offers.  It does an excellent job of setting up anticipation and capturing the tension of making quick decisions ("killing" the killer is often not as easy as it seems.. just like in the movies that this game is making satire of, the bad guy has a problem with staying dead).  Controlling mutilated people is surprisingly fun, as well--as your plan falls apart and whoever is left surviving might not be fully intact.
I cannot wait to see the future episodes.

Allowing you to do everything from having an orgy to murdering your friends ontop of the fight to survive the maniacs who try to kill you, an unlockable mode, and a secret boss, I had an absolute blast playing this game.

I think my game hates me.

talking with others they had this tense, building, frightful experience that gradually swelled to the reveal of the killer is loose.  Meanwhile, I was bumrushed by the killer my first 4 playthroughs, and didn't have ANY atmospheric buildup until attempt 5.  At that point I was ready to just go hard for the killer, so I didn't care, there was no suspense, it was just frustrating to have all these laid out traps then have to wait for the guy to get around to spawning.

All the difficulty is figuring out the basics of what things are, where things are and what to do.  After that it's a cakewalk.  The AI is super predictable, the killer's easily tracked for his every move.  Maybe this gets better with the later episodes but the starting episode did not impress me at all.

Maybe I'd feel differently if I had time to goof around, or a clear way to trigger the monster/killer portion of it, or had gotten more of the atmosphere.  Maybe I'll try for all the achievements next, but the game came off as more tedium than fun.

15499415.review:
I heavily recommend this game. Lakeview Cabin is a sidescrolling game with pretty simple graphics, and a rather interesting concept. While it may look simple, the gameplay is actually pretty complex and requires planning, tactics, and timing. This is technically an episodic series, and as of this writing, there is only one episode out (Other than the secret one). The first episide's plot is simple: you're playing as a bunch of teenagers in a summer camp on an island, which gets invaded by various killers, and your goal is to kill them, or be killed yourself. The main draw of this game is that there's no single path to take as you dispatch the killers. There's a [b]TON[/b] of options and variety - but at the same time, you'll have to do a TON of experimenting and planning to see what does and does not work. It's... pretty trial and error, honestly. While I don't like that brand of gameplay, it's pretty rewarding once you succeed. However, if your plan fails even slightly, most of the time you're better off just starting from scratch. Alternatively, you can do whatever the hell you want - the game doesn't [i]punish[/i] you until the killers come. So, for shits and giggles, you can play out your very own 80's horror movie scenario! Once you figure out how things work, now comes the fun part! A thing I love about this game is that you can't take the killers on up front: you have to either trap them, or put them in a vulnerable state, before you attack. Meaning planning, planning, planning. You're going have to prepare and set things up before they arrive or you're screwed. Seriously. Don't even try it if you're not prepared. You won't win.

To say something negative about the game... it's pretty difficult, to the point of being unfair. You're probably better off looking up a walkthrough. And like pretty much every horror game, the fright factor dissipates... pretty quickly. After a few run ins with the monster, it becomes predictable as you [i]know[/i] when it's going to show up. Fortunately, the game doesn't bombard you with jump scares (I don't recall a single jumpscare!), most of the horror comes from the "oh shit, is it here yet!?" suspense... which wears off the second you realize the [i]obvious[/i] cues. Honestly, I don't regard this as too much of a horror game, because of the aforementioned reasons. Oh yeah, there's also the simplistic graphics - but that shouldn't be too much of a problem if you can handle "retro" graphics. Which is honestly better than attempts at shitty dreamcast era 3D.

All in all, Lakeview is a pretty fun game that has a surprising amount of depth and gameplay, albeit with it lacking in graphics and being incredibly difficult. But hey, it's worth the five dollars you'll spend on this. 

... Writing this was probably a waste of time. It'll just get buried under all the attempts to be [i]funny[/i]. >_>

I can't wait to see three more episodes of this!
It's basically a problem solving game. But it's wearing a Friday the 13th mask and wielding an axe. It's funny and frightening in equal measures and it looks and sounds awesome.
A controller is recomended to play, but the keys are rebindable, so it's fine without. The menu options are a little (very) limited and there's no health bar/inventories/tool tips or any other guidance to help you along! But that didn't really detract from this refreshingly different approach to survival horror.

15315339.review:
非常有趣的像素风格恐怖游戏，而且比较有挑战性，切入点和设计上都比较巧妙，画面在同类像素游戏中已算不错了。有时候自己的失误会出现戏剧性的结果，令人感到啼笑皆非。游戏中每一步都要算计好，没错，是算计好！布置好陷阱、调配好四人等待杀人狂魔和怪物的出现。激战时的BGM也很带感。游戏虽然不大，但是玩起来有多周目的趣味性，并不是通关之后就没得玩了，还可以换不同方法反复挑战。而且作者许诺会继续更新后面三章，所以一次性买了合集，感觉作者还是挺良心的。

总结：是一款相当不错的游戏，无论你是否喜欢像素风格都值得入手一玩！

-I don't really have any yet - don't get me wrong though - this isn't perfect, just quirky

I am enjoying it so far.

15307534.review:
Lakeview Cabin is best known for the flash game that has been circulating the internet for a while, portraying a peaceful scenario, where you seemingly have the freedom to do whatever you want without a guideline up until the point where everything turns gruesome as you are hunted down by a monster.
The current episode released (Lakeview Cabin III) goes by that same formula, except with 4 characters that can be played to make survival possible (Or you let everyone hide and only one person does all the work).
This game gives you a setting and basicly allows you to re-enact scenarios reminiscent of 80's slasher fics, where you decide on how to dispatch/survive your pursuers and wether or not your friends live or die (by the murderer's hands or even your own) and giving you a sense of freedom to set up your own horror movie.

+Simple, yet pleasing graphics
+Random spawning time for the murderers (they seem to either spawn early or late or depending on what you do)
+Many ways to dispatch/hinder/distract your pursuers
+Gruesome deaths and in some cases the corpses get strung up by the murderer after switching away from the corpse
+Get drunk, get high and have a bisexual foursome

-We need more ! (<- not an actual complaint.)

On a personal note: This is one of the few horror games I've played lately where I've actually been afraid, so I have taken quite a bit of enjoyment out of it so far and look forward to further episodes. Keep on doing what you're doing, dev. It's great and my money has been well spent !

15302103.review:
This is story of four friends, who decided to be Camp Counselors. One of them rides out into town to get supplies but dies in an accident. The three oblivious friends do drugs and fool around, thinking their friend is still in town. 
One of them finds it odd that their friend has been gone for a whole night. She leaves the two others to pork in the cabin while she discovers their dead friend. 
Thinking that he was murdered, she takes their dog and hides it in the cabin where her two friends are making love. She explores the camp on her own to find scary messages painted on the cabins such as "Come and Play".
She ends up falling in the dark and loosing her foot. Then she manages to find a gun just in time to defend herself from some unknown figure in the darkness. 
She limps back to the cabin where her friends are at but she is attacked by a masked stranger. She realizes she is out of ammo and runs for the cabin. She is slaughtered inches away from the door.
The two love birds finally stop after hearing the screams of their friend. The guy decides to go check it out and sees the masked man.
He runs back inside and is stabbed to death along with the dog. The masked man leaves, not seeing the final counselor hiding in the closet. The nude survivor runs out of the cabin to the dock. She finds an axe and tries to defend herself against the masked man but she ends up suffering the same fate as her friends.

This is the my first thirty minutes of experience with the game. Very funny and terrifying at the same time.

13/10

15299353.review:
Played Lakeview Cabin from the Humble Bundle store for over 3 hours. It's not just a game. It's... something entirely different. You turn into this potential murder (you can kill your friends if you wish to) even though the objective is to survive the horrors of each chapter. It captures the essence of 80s horror movies exceptionally well with a lot of goofiness moments and easter eggs (if you're a fan of horror movies you're gonna love Lakeview Cabin). Considering you can replay each of every episode and have different results and find new secrets, Lakeview Cabin is a bargain.

If you wish to see it in action you're more than welcome to check this video (let's play):

15298807.review:
Really interesting game. It's sandbox survival that perfectly encapsulates the tension of B-grade slasher flicks. You're given control of 4 survivors at once, all of which are about as useless as you'd expect if you've seen the genre before. 

Needless to say, this game is extremely difficult, as by the first night you'll more often than not be under attack from a few enemies at once, each of which is vastly stronger than your party combined. This, admittedly makes for a good challenge, however, when you're done screwing around with all of the tools and mechanics at your disposal, the core gameplay comes down to memorizing how to unlock various items and where to collect them. 

It's fun to kick around in and definitely worth the modest price tag, but be sure to play in private; the true horror experience comes from trying to explain to a loved one, or housemate, that having an ingame orgy is crucial to your survival.

Je démarre avec un barbu. Je me fous à poil, je me descends une vingtaine de bière, impossible de bien voir. Je vais copuler avec la rousse. 
Je prends le contrôle du roux, je me ballade, j'explore. Puis je prends la brune, je fais un tour de moto, j'écrase le chien, et je me suicide dans le lac. Je prends le controle du premier barbu qui copule, un mec entre avec une hache, nous tue, tout les 2. Je décide de me cacher avec le dernier survivant. Je marche, je vois la rousse, pendue et éviscérée à une maison, par le tueur; oklm.
Je vais dans la cuisine, j'allume le four, il prend feu, je meurs.
10/10.
Non, sérieusement, ce jeu, c'est du n'importe quoi. C'est impossible de pas rire, tout les clichés y sont. C'est un mini sandbox de Vendredi 13, et c'est l'occasion de voir si ce que nous aurions fait à la place des ados cons dans les films d'horreur nous aurait sauvé. En général, non.
J'attends avec impatience les autres films (Evil Dead ? Scream ? Massacre à la Tronçonneuse?...).


EDIT 26/07/2015 (MàJ ajout de l'épisode Massacre à la Tronçonneuse)

Enfin ! Un nouvel épisode... Le deuxième depuis la sortie du jeu sur Steam. Massacre à la Tronçonneuse, vous ne pouvez pas imaginer la joie que j'ai eu... un de mes films préférés!... hop je lance le jeu, impatient...
Puis 20 minutes plus tard, je me demande... qu'est-ce qu'il s'est passé, au juste, dans la tête du dev ?
Dans le "premier" épisode, l'univers était simple, autant niveau compréhension des mécanismes que visuellement, les délires étaient accessibles (se bourrer la gueule, partouzer, puis se faire défoncer la rondelle à coup de hache par deux tueurs) et drôles, c'était un peu ça le piment du jeu... l'univers loufoque avec une ambiance malsaine !
Bon. Rapidement. Ici, comme évoqué plus haut, c'est Leatherface et sa ferme qui est à l'honneur. Donc forcément, vous vous dites famille cannibale, etc, ça va être marrant !
Non, pas vraiment... On démarre avec 4 persos, tous des filles, et hop, un screamer qui vous fera des dégats. Donc, vous allez devoir changer de persos assez rapidement pour vous cacher dans le van derrière vous pour ne prendre aucun dégat, vu que le truc va vous foncer dessus et bousculer vos characters (pour un die and retry c'est assez lourd cette manip : pas à droite, touche haut, espace, 4 fois d'affilée pour se planquer). Donc bon, niveau immersion c'est déjà pas terrible terrible... Puis dans le premier, on voyait que les persos en vacances étaient clichés et bien 80's, là on a aucune idée de ce qu'on fout ici, on démarre devant un van, enfermé dans une zone de jeu ridiculement petite, avec 4 persos souriants. (???)

Bon allez, on accélère. Vous avez trois batiments : l'abattoir, un bordel pas possible avec des pièges sans queue ni tête (des lance-flammes à côté des scies pour découper les porcs, et un espèce de truc difforme qui balance un liquide (qui vous one shot?...) tout ça pour arriver à une salle avec LE gros méchant. Et là c'est encore plus sympa parce qu'il faut faire marche arrière forcément, avec des salles qui apparaissent comme par magie à la place des portes dans lesquelles vous êtes passé, etc. Faudra regarder les trous de la serrure, mais vous inquiétez pas, le méchant est très très lent, vous pouvez vous faire un café en attendant...
Ensuite, vous avez la maison familiale. Bon... après l'abattoir, vous vous dites qu'enfin vous allez rencontrer la famille cannibale!... 
non.
Encore moins de logique que ce que j'ai précédemment évoqué... :/ J'entends par là : vous verrez énormément d'ennemis tous aussi débiles les uns que les autres (vous entrez dans une salle, vous vous prenez un coup, vous ressortez, même si le mec a un pied de biche, il ne vous pourchassera pas, il préfèrera faire les 100 pas dans sa salle de 10M carrés. Heureusement, ils sont pas résistants, m'enfin... il doit y avoir une dizaine de salles, avec des sado-masos, des vieux papys qui vous démontent à mains nues, vous la jeunette de 20 piges, un rat difforme de 1M de haut, un clown, deux gars en combi jaunes etc, des items sans aucune logique (une spirale qui hypnotise en faisant de la musique, sérieux?... on est loin des 2 tueurs du premier qui supportaient pas les crissements de la radio...) et des ennemis chiants, mous, tous aussi différents les uns que les autres. Aucune indication sur ce qu'il faut faire, on tourne en rond, avec ces 200 barils d'essence qui butent TOUT LE MONDE - même vous - dans la salle, des endroits qui se ferment à clé comme par magie, et surtout... cette alarme insupportable. vous la désactivez, elle revient deux secondes après, et ça n'attire aucun ennemi. Aucun intérêt...

En conclusion, et j'ai oublié un tas de trucs, le premier épisode est juste génial et drôle : le deuxième n'est absolument pas drôle, (à part si prendre un bain dans de l'eau sale vous fait rire, perso j'ai trouvé plus amusant de jeter un moustachu à poil défoncé à l'herbe dans une machine pour couper du bois) illogique, et surtout, vraiment... Ce level design totalement foiré, on comprend rien, il y a trop de détails, la caméra s'affole toute seule en penchant de droite à gauche alors que vous n'avez rien pris, ces ennemis qui regardent la télé puis qui disparaissent tout seuls, ou encore le fait que vous prendrez des dégats dans le vent, vous ne saurez même pas si le jeu est buggé ou si le level design trop chargé vous a niqué. Et on mentionnera les trappes invisibles aussi, ainsi que les pièges à clous dans la salle à manger. Allez devant, appuyez sur action, bravo, un perso est mort?... Je ne cherche plus, ce deuxième épisode est foiré de A à Z. 
On espère que le dev fera des trucs plus sympas plus tard, j'ai cru comprendre qu'un niveau à la Halloween était le suivant, puis un autre sur Alien. On croise les doigts...

This is a puzzle game in the form of a retro B-Movie horror flick. 
Your objective is to survive. 
You do this by utilizing your four "sexy companions" to set off traps in order to defeat the killer.

Gameplay is exploring and trying out various items to see what is effective.
Has a good presentation and atmosphere. 

If you ever screamed at the survivors in a horror movie to do something different or fight back; now is your chance to see if you could survive and help your friends not take an axe to the face.
